implementing_agencies: China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC), State-owned Company
title: Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project (Phase I): Preferential Buyer's Credit Facility (linked to #33463 and #33452)
description: On 9 September 2006, China Eximbank signed a USD 455 million financing agreement with Sri Lanka for Phase I of the Norochcholai Coal Power Project in Puttalam, which is also referred to as the Puttalam Coal Power Project (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization' for the commitment date). This financing agreement consists of two components, a USD 155 million buyer's credit facility (not preferential) and a USD 300 million preferential buyer's credit facility (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2009 Annual Performance Report). For the purpose of this project, only details related to the USD 300 million preferential buyer's credit facility have been recorded. For details regarding the USD 155 million (non-preferential) buyer's credit facility, see project ID #33463. According to the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus, the USD 455 million of Chinese financing covered the total cost of the project. The main components of this project include the installation of a 300MW coal power plant, a jetty for coal handling, and transmission lines from Norochcholai to Veyangoda and substation at Veyangoda. The power plant constructed under the scope of this project is known as the Lakvijaya Power Station or the Norochcholai Power Station (see Sri Lanka Ministry of Power, Energy and Business Development). According to the Sri Lanka Ministry of Power, Energy and Business Development, the USD 300 million preferential buyer's credit facility has an interest rate of 2%. Phase I construction began on 23 July 2007 and was completed in March 2010. The contractor for this project was China Machinery Engineering Corporation. For information on Phase II, see project ID #33452.

implementing_agencies: China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd., State-owned Company
title: China aids Sri Lanka in rebuilding fishery harbours after tsunami
description: China came forward to reconstruct three fishery harbours affected by the 2004 tsunami- the Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela fishery harbours, which are located in Sri Lanka's western and southern coasts. China funded Rs. 900 million for the Panadura, Beruwala and Kudawella harbours. Commencing in early 2005, the three projects were completed ahead of schedule by the China Harbour Engineering Company. STAFF_NOTES: China contributed 63 million USD for tsunami relief in total. Most individual projects are captured in our database, and linked to resource #41811.

implementing_agencies: China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd., State-owned Company; SinoHydro, State-owned Company
title: Hambantota Port Development Project - Phase I (link to project ID #33409)
description: On 30 December 2007, China EXIM Bank signed a 306.7 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Hambantota Port Development Project - Phase I (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'). The interest rate is 6.3%, with a four-year grace period and fifteen-year maturity. Construction began on 15 January 2008, and the project was finished on October 30, 2011 (opened ceremonially early -November 2010 -to coincide with the president's birthday; phase two also began on this day). The scope of the project involved the construction of two nos of breakwaters(312m long eastern b/w and 988m long western b/w), a 17m deep harbor basin, a 210m wide entrance channel, a service berth, 100,000DWT general purpose berth, 100,000 DWT oil berth, and various roads and buildings-Admin Building, Public Service Building and Utility Buildings. The contractors for this project were China Harbor Engineering Co. and Sinohydro. The total cost of the project was about 507 million USD, so the China Eximbank loan accounted for about 60% of the total project cost (see Government of Sri Lanka 2017 Bond Prospectus). In 2013, China Exim Bank provided an additional CNY 960 million concessional loan for Hambantota Port Development Phase I for Ancillary Works and Supply of Equipment (see project ID #33409). EXIM Bank had also provided a US$65 million loan for the bunkering terminal (See Project ID#33329) and US$809.35 million for Hambantota Port Develoment Project Phase II (See Project ID#33481).

implementing_agencies: China National Machinery and Equipment Import & Export Corporation, State-owned Company
title: Supply of 15 Diesel Multiple Units for Sri Lanka Railways
description: According to the 2007 Annual Report from the Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance, China committed a loan of 38,683,633 USD in 2017 for the supply of 15 diesel multiple units (power train sets) to Sri Lanka (see p. 351). The power train sets would be supplied to Sri Lanka by China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC). This is part of efforts to modernize the Sri Lankan Railway system and reduce inconvenience caused to commuters travelling from Colombo to the sub urban areas and on the Kelani Valley route. According to the 2008 Annual Report from the Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance, this project was under implementation in 2008 (see p. 214). The first 3 batches were scheduled to reach Colombo by August 2008, and the other 12 train sets were to be delivered in two batches of 6 in September and December 2008. According to the 2010 Annual Report, the project was completed in 2009 (see p. 192 of 2009 Annual Report & p. 322 of 2010 Annual Report). It is worth noting that in 2007 China also committed a loan for the provision of 100 carriages to Sri Lanka (see project ID #33275), and in 2010 China committed a loan for the provision of an additional 13 diesel multiple units (see project ID #49343).

implementing_agencies: World Food Program (WFP), Multilateral
title: China gives Sri Lanka 270 tons of canned fish worth $320,000 USD as part of its tsunami relief efforts
description: China gave 270 tons of canned fish worth320,000 USD to Sri Lanka as part of its tsunami relief efforts. The aid was administered by the World Food Programme (WFP). It is the first of two such shipments, worth a total of US$1 million, to support WFP food-for-work schemes to help Sri Lanka after the tsunami. STAFF_NOTES: China contributed 63 million USD for tsunami relief in total, most of the individual projects are captured (see projects linked with resource #41811).

contacts: James Morris, Executive Director (World Food Program (WFP))

title: China donates 1 million Sri Lankan Rupees in disaster relief aid
description: On October 3, 2008 China donated 1 million Sri Lanka Rupees to Sri Lanka to help those affected by recent floods and landslides. Chinese Ambassador Ye Dabo handed over the donation to Sri Lankan Disaster Management and Human Rights Minister Mahinda Samarasinghe.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=DAINSL0020081103e4a300005&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Ye Dabo, Chinese Ambassador; Mahinda Samarasinghe, Disaster Managmement and Human Rights Minister

implementing_agencies: China National Machinery and Equipment Import & Export Corporation, State-owned Company
title: Procurement of 100 Carriages for Sri Lanka Railways
description: According to the 2007 Annual Report from the Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance, China committed a loan of 27,078,543 USD in 2017 for the supply of 100 railway passenger carriages to Sri Lanka (see p. 351). The passenger carriages would be supplied to Sri Lanka by China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC). According to the 2008 Annual Report from the Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance, this project was completed in 2008 (see p. 214). It is worth noting that in 2007 China also committed a loan for the provision of 15 diesel multiple units (power train sets) to Sri Lanka (see project ID #33260), and in 2010 China committed a loan for the provision of an additional 13 diesel multiple units (see project ID #49343).

title: China donates 1 million USD as emergency relief to Sri Lanka for Internally Displaced Persons
description: On May 12, 2009 China donated 1 million USD to Sri Lanka as emergency relief for Internally Displaced Persons who had fled the LTTE as civilians. The donation was handed over by Chinese Ambassador Yang Xiuping to Foreign Minister Rohitha Bogollagama at the Ministry in Colombo.

title: China donates 20 million yuan worth of tents to Sri Lanka
description: In May 2009, China donated 20 million yuan (2.93 million US dollars) worth of tents to Sri Lanka. The tents will be sent to Sri Lanka in four batches and is part of China's humanitarian for around 200,000 Tamil civilians displaced by the conflict between the government and the LTTE.

implementing_agencies: China Huanqiu Contracting & Engineering Corporation, State-owned Company
title: Hambantota Bunkering Project (also known as Bunkering Facility & Tank Farm Project)
description: On 8 June 2009, China Exim Bank signed a 65 million USD loan agreement with the Sri Lankan government for the construction of a bunkering facility at the new Hambantota Port, known as the Hambantota Bunkering Project or the Bunkering Facility & Tank Farm Project. The contract for the project was awarded to the China Huanqiu Contracting and Engineering Corporation. The loan has a maturity of 15 years including 3 years of grace period. The interest rate is not found. The total project amount was listed as US$96 million, but it is unclear who will be providing the remaining funding. According to the China Huanqiu Contracting & Engineering Co. website, the mechanical works for this project were completed on 10 October 2011, and according to the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources the project reached full completion on 8 June 2012. STAFF_NOTE: Because the interest rate is not specified in available resources, the flow class has been coded as Vague (Official Finance). The bunkering facility and tank farm was located 1.2km from the waterfront, and will be connected to the oil terminal through a pipeline. The facility has 14 tanks (total storage of 80,000 m3). Bunkering operations began in 2014, and are run by the SPLA; these operation were suspended due to a loss of19.9 million as a result of irregularities.

title: China pledges to aid Sri Lanka with 10th South Asian Games
description: China pledged to provide grant assistance Sri Lanka for the 10th South Asian Games. Two agreements were signed for the technical and economic cooperation to develop the country's economy and sports equipment to help Sri Lanka to hold the 10th South Asian Games. No further details could be found specifying the nature and form of aid to be offered beyond what was stated in the article. According to the Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance and Planning Annual Report, China committed400,000 allocated for the games.

title: China donates meteorology equipment to Sri Lanka
description: In May 2006, China donated meteorology equipment to Sri Lanka to help improve the island country's weather forecast standard. The donation included temperature-humidity sensors, rainfall sensors and battery cabinets, among others.
sources: http://www.gov.cn/misc/2006-05/16/content_281265.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020060515e25f001ny&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

implementing_agencies: China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd., State-owned Company; China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC), State-owned Company; China Railway No. 5 Engineering Group Co. Ltd, ; Sinohydro Corporation, State-owned Company
title: Northern Road Rehabilitation Project
description: On 9 September 2010, EXIM Bank of China signed a 424 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka to finance the the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project. The loan has an interest rate of LIBOR 06 Month for US$ + 2.40% margin and a maturity of 15 years including 3 years of grace period (see 'Global Partnership' document from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in September 2010 was 0.478%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.478% + 2.40%, or 2.878%. According to the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources, this project was completed on 9 September 2013. On 6 December 2009, The Sunday Times of Sri Lanka reported that the contract to rehabilitate (widen and improve) all adjunct roads in the North of Sri Lanka had been given to four different Chinese companies in 13 different packages. The four Chinese companies, China National Aero Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC), China Harbour, China Railway No 5 Engineering Group Co. Ltd. and Synohydro Corporation will share the deals between them. Based on Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources (ERD) the project has 7 packages, which corroborated with the 'Development Performance Year End Review 2014' report by Sri Lanka's Ministry of Finance and Planning and the summary report by Ministry of Highways, Higher Education and Investment Promotion. The 7 contract packages are: 1) C1A - 63 km of Kandy- Jaffna road (From Galkulama to 230th km). Contractor: CATIC 2) C1B- 90 km of Kandy- Jaffna road (From 230th km to Jaffna). Contractor: CATIC 3) C11A - 42.4km of Mullaitivu- Kokkilai- Pulmoddai road. 4) C11B - 52.6 km of Oddusuddan- Nedunkerny road and Mullaitivu- Puliyankulam road. 5) C2 - 67 km of Navatkuli- Karaitivu- Mannar road (completed in 2015). Contractor: China Harbour Engineering Corporation 6) C3 - 113 km of Puttalam- Marichchikade- Mannar road (completed in 2015). Contractor: China Harbour Engineering Corporation 7) C7 - 84 km of Jaffna- Kankesanthurai road, Jaffna- Palali road, Jaffna- Point Pedro Road and Puttur - Meesalai road. Contractor: China Railway No. 5 Engineering Group C7 stretches for 84km and itself comprises of 3 sub-projects 1)Jaffna-Kankesanthurai road (Route No. AB16), 2) Jaffna-Palali road, Jaffna-Point Pedro Road (Route No. AB18 and AB20 respectively) and 3) Puttur-Meesalai road (Route No. AB32 ) . The project was jointly funded by the Exim Bank of China & the Government of Sri Lanka. The Project was valued at Rs. 3,662 Million. Construction began on Feb 11, 2011 and was completed on Oct 13, 2013. One source stated that the projects would be executed under 5 civil works contracts, and that 5 loans were signed by Exim bank on 09.09.2010 to satisfy these contracts. This was the only source to break down the projects in this way. STAFF_NOTE: The ERD Performance Report of 2010 reported the loan to be US$302 million, but their current website sites the loan as worth US$424 million. Because both are official sources but it is likely that their site is a more recent source, this project records the amount of US$424 million. A 2015 report lists the value at Rs.59632 Mn.

title: China donates 2,000 tents worth 128 million Rupees to Sri Lanka (Linked to #33289)
description: In December 2009, China donated 2,000 tents, valued at 128 million Rupees, to help civilians who have been displaced from their homes by the civil war in North Sri Lanka.

implementing_agencies: China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd., State-owned Company
title: Hambantota International Airport (also known as Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport or Southern International Airport)
description: STAFF_NOTE: Confirmed by Director- China and AIIB Division, External Resources Department, Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, Sri Lanka In 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China gave Sri Lanka a190 million concessional loan for the construction of the Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport (also known as Hambantota International Airport or the Southern International Airport) in the city of Hambantota which is located in southeast Sri Lanka. The airport is being constructed by the China Harbour Engineering Company, their first airport construction project ever taken. The total cost of the airport was US$209 million. The goal of this project was to provide an alternative airport, located in Mattala, for the Bandaranaike international Airport. The project involved the construction of a 4Km loan runway, a parking apron, a taxiway connecting the runaway and the apron, a terminal building, cargo storage, a fuel arm, and a fire service building. The project has two phases. Construction began on March 5, 2010, and the entire Phase-1 construction was completed in 2012 while the entire project was finished on March 5th, 2014. While some reports quoted a loan amount of US$209 million, Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources (ERD) quoted a loan amount of US$190 million.

title: China donates 50M rupees worth of de-mining detectors and equipment to Sri Lanka
description: In March 2010, China donated a stock of de-mining equipment worth 50 million rupees to Sri Lanka to help de-mining activities in the Northern region. Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka Yang Xiuping handed over 50 de-mining detectors and 50 de-mining protective equipment kits to Sri Lanka Prime Minister Rathnasiri Wickramanayaka. The donation is expected to accelerate ongoing army de-mining operations in the north as part of resettlement, reconstruction, and rehabilitation efforts taking place under the 'Uthuru Wasanthaya' (Northern Spring) program.

implementing_agencies: Sri Lanka-China Friendship Association, Foundation
title: China donates books to Sri Lankan schools
description: Exercise books were donated to Dhamma Schools of Gautama Viharaya at Green Park, Narahenpita, Sri Naga Viharaya Kotte, Royal College Colombo, Thilakerathnaramaya Borella and Sri Seewali Dhamma School of Sri Nagaviharaya at Baseline Road. The Sri Lanka-China Friendship Association has made arrangements to distribute books to needy Dhamma Schools in Sri Lanka under the patronage of the Buddhist Association of China (role unclear). This is the second phase of book donation by the Sri Lanka-China Friendship Association. The first phase of the distribution of exercise books was held on June 19, 2011.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=DAINSL0020110704e7750005q&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://sl-china.net/?p=20, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
recipient_agencies: Sri Lanka-China Friendship Association, Foundation
location_details: Gautama Viharaya at Green Park, Narahenpita, Sri Naga Viharaya Kotte, Royal College Colombo, Thilakerathnaramaya Borella and Sri Seewali Dhamma School of Sri Nagaviharaya at Baseline Road

implementing_agencies: Aerospace Long-March International Trade Co., Ltd, ; China National Electric Import & Export Corporation, State-owned Company; Faculty of Architecture, University of Moratuwa, Academic, Training and Research
title: EXIM Bank loans Sri Lanka USD104.3 million for Lotus Tower
description: Sri Lanka and China have signed an agreement for the construction of the South Asia's tallest tower, a multi-faceted telecommunication tower and leisure park that will be named the Lotus Tower ('Nelum Kuluna'). The project will be completed by the end of 2015. The Telecommunication Regulatory Commission of Sri Lanka will finance and implement the project with technical assistance from the Faculty of Architecture of the University of Moratuwa. A Chinese conglomerate comprising China National Electronics Import and Export Corporation and Aerospace Long-March International Trade Co.Ltd., will complete the project on a turnkey basis.The construction is estimated to cost 104.3 Million U.S.Dollars and it will be funded by China EXIM Bank. Recently, the Sri Lankan government has announced that the 'Lotus Tower'' project is to be reviewed, in order to assess whether the construction of the tower should continue. Sri Lanka's Ports and Aviation Minister Arjuna Ranatunga claims that construction is taking place on land that belongs to the Ports Authority without proper government protocol. As of 2019 March, the project is expected to be completed by 2020. STAFF_NOTE: This project is confirmed by Director of China and AIIB Division, External Resources Department, Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, Sri Lanka

recipient_agencies: Faculty of Architecture, University of Moratuwa, Academic, Training and Research; Telecommunication Regulatory Commission of Sri Lanka, Government Agency
contacts: Anusha Pelpita, The Director General of the Telecommunication Regulatory Commission

title: China donates 10 million yuan of humanitarian aid for flood relief in Sri Lanka
description: In January 2011, China donated 10 million yuan worth of humanitarian aid to flood-ravaged Sri Lanka. The 70-tonnes materials include 30,000 bags of milk powder, 30,000 bags of sugar, 10,000 pieces towel, 10,000 bed sheet, 7,200 blankets and 60 sets of water purifiers. Link to project #38917, which was donated at the same time.

title: Provision of Sporting Goods for Youth in Jaffna, Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu
description: On 4 May 2012, the Chinese government signed a 1 million CNY grant agreement with Sri Lanka for the provision of sporting goods for the youth in Jaffna, Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2012 Annual Performance Report). The sports equipment was delivered to Colombo in December 2012, and on 18 January 2013 Ambassador Wu Jianghao and the Sri Lanka Foreign Minister Peiris signed a handover certificate (see January 2013 article from China's Ministry of Commerce).
sources: http://lk.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201301/20130100006448.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.treasury.gov.lk/reports/annualreport/2012/6-FinacingBudget.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/ERD%20Performance%20Report%202012%20-English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=MENREP0020130121e91l0004x&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China donates heavy machinery and equipment to Sri Lanka for post-war reconstruction
description: In 2010, China signed a transfer certificate with Sri Lanka regarding the donation of heavy machinery and equipment. China donated 34 heavy machinery and equipment worth over 285.4 million Sri Lanka Rupees for infrastructure development in north and east Sri Lanka. The equipment will be used for the rehabilitation and reconstruction of war-torn areas.
sources: http://lk.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t658484.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.colombopage.com/archive_10/Feb1266167233CH.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=TARGNS0020100217e62f001qi&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Yang Xiuping, Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka

implementing_agencies: China National Machinery and Equipment Import & Export Corporation, State-owned Company
title: Matara Beliatta Section of Matara Kataragama Railway Extension: Preferential Buyer's Credit (link to project ID #33407)
description: On 19 February 2013, China's EXIM Bank signed a 200 million USD preferential buyer's credit agreement with Sri Lanka to finance the Matara- Beliatta Section of the Matara-Kataragama Railway Extension Project (phase I). The loan will be provided at an annual interest rate of 2% with a repayment period of 20 years including a seven year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2013 Annual Performance Report). The total cost of the project is 278.2 million USD; EXIM Bank is also providing a concessional loan of 508 million CNY (see project ID #33407). This project began on 19 February 2013 and was completed on 31 December 2018 (see 'Resource Mobilization' from the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). Construction was carried out by China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CNMIEC). The main goal of the project is to improve transport in the southern region. This project involves the construction of 26.75km length of single line broad gauge rail track from Matara to Beliatta; the construction of structures such as culverts, bridges, viaducts those required over the Nilwala river flood plain, level crossings, underpasses, overpasses, and tunnels; as well as the construction of four numbers railway crossing stations, 2 numbers sub stations and functional requirements of stations (see 'Resource Mobilization').

implementing_agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC), State-owned Company; Hunan Constructing Engineering Group Corporation, State-owned Company; Xi'an Dagang Road Machinery Co., Ltd.,
title: Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase I (PRP3-I) (link to projects ID #46971, #39001 and #39002)
description: On 11 March 2014, the China Development Bank signed a 300 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Improvement and Rehabilitation of Priority Road Project 3 (Phase I), which was a follow-up on a May 2013 pledge from CDB for the same amount. According to the 2017 Sri Lanka Government Bond Prospectus, the estimated total cost of the project was 357.69 million USD. The Government of Sri Lanka would provide the remaining funds for the project. The 300 million USD CDB loan has an interest rate of LIBOR 06 Months for US$ + 2.95% margin and a repayment period of 15 years including a 3 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2014 Annual Performance Report). The interest rate is coded based on the 6 Month LIBOR at time of signing of the agreement. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in March 2014 was 0.331%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.331% + 2.95%, or 3.281%. This project commenced on 11 March 2014 and was completed on 11 March 2019 (see 'Resource Mobilization' from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The objective of this project was to rehabilitate and improve 270 km of priority road sections to ensure the connectivity among already improved road sections. Areas of the project include: Southern, Eastern, Uva, Western and Sabaragamuwa Provinces. The Sri Lanka Department of External Resources divides Priority Road Project 3 (PRP3) Phase I into two parts, A and B. The contractors for PRP3-Phase I (A) were China National Aero-Technology International Engineering (CATIC - ENG) and Xi'an Dagang Machinery Co. Ltd., although it is unclear which specific roads each company worked on. The contractors for PRP3-Phase I (B) were CATIC and Hunan Construction Engineering Group Corporation (Hunan), and the specific contractor for each road is listed in the relevant section below. Under PRP3- Phase I (A) the following 6 roads were rehabilitated (see Ministry of Highways and Investment 'Ongoing Projects'): 1. Ratnapura - Palawela - Karawita Road: 00.00km - 21.28 km 2. Veyangoda -Ruwanwella Road: 12.4 km - 32.2 km (19.8 km total length). This section also included the rehabilitation of a bridge. 3. Meegahajandura-Kumaragama Road: 0.00 km - 8.8 km 4. Galle-Udugama Road: 0.00 km - 35.35 km 5. Hiniduma-Opatha-Pitabaddara Road: 0.00 km - 31.5 km. This section also included the rehabilitation of a bridge. 6. Mawanella-Hemmathagama-Gampola Road: 0.00 km - 26.00 km Under PRP3 - Phase I (B) the following 6 roads were rehabilitated (see Ministry of Highways and Investment 'Ongoing Projects'): 7. Kiriella-Nedurana-Eheliyagoda Road: 0.00 km - 14.75 km. Contractor: CATIC 8. Ratnapura-Wewelwatte Road: 0.00 km - 27.50 km. Contractor: CATIC 9. Kandy-Jaffna Road: 1.65 km - 3.9 km (2.25 km total length). Contractor: Hunan 10. Marawila-Udubaddawa Road: 0.00 km - 19.55 km. Contractor: Hunan 11. Rambukkana-Katupitiya Road (0.00 km - 9.81 km) and Dambokka-Katupitiya Road (0.00 km - 8.75 km). These two roads were rehabilitated at the same time and are considered the same project by the Sri Lanka Ministry of Highways and Investment. Contractor: Hunan 12. Ayagama-Egaloya Road: 0.00 km - 23.00 km. Contractor: CATIC For other priority road projects, see projects ID #46971 (PRP1), #39001 (PRP2), and #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

title: Matara Beliatta Section of Matara Kataragama Railway Extension: Concessional Loan (link to project ID #33396)
description: On 28 May 2013, EXIM Bank signed a 508 million CNY concessional loan agreement with Sri Lanka to finance the Matara-Beliatta Section of the Matara-Kataragama Railway Extension Project. The loan has an interest rate of 2% with a repayment period of 20 years including a seven year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2013 Annual Performance Report). The total cost of the project is 278.2 million USD, with the remainder of the funds coming from a China Eximbank 200 million USD preferential buyer's credit (see project ID #33396). This project began on 19 February 2013 and was completed on 31 December 2018 (see 'Resource Mobilization' from the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The main goal of the project is to improve transport in the southern region. This project involves the construction of 26.75km length of single line broad gauge rail track from Matara to Beliatta; the construction of structures such as culverts, bridges, viaducts those required over the Nilwala river flood plain, level crossings, underpasses, overpasses, and tunnels; as well as the construction of four numbers railway crossing stations, 2 numbers sub stations and functional requirements of stations (see 'Resource Mobilization').

title: Hambantota Port Development Project Phase I - Ancillary Works & Supply of Equipment Project (linked to #33256)
description: On 24 March 2013, China and Sri Lanka signed a CNY 960 million concessional loan agreement for the Hambantota Port Development Phase I - Ancillary Works and Supply of Equipment. The loan would be provided by China Eximbank to deepen the harbor basin one additional meter, dredge for approaching channel, provide additional work on the oil terminal, generate breakwater and revetment modification and handling facilities, provide a new administration and services building, and change specification of navigational aid and price escalation. The loan has a fixed interest rate of 2%, a grace period of 5 years and a maturity of 20 years (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources Performance Report 2013, page 52 of PDF). Project implementation began on 24 April 2013 and was completed on 24 April 2015.

title: China Development Bank loans $49m to Sri Lanka Hatton Bank
description: Description: In June 2013 Sri Lanka's Hatton National Bank signed a deal with the China Development Bank for a 5 year long 49 million USD loan for raising capital. The agreement was signed by Dr Ranee Jayamaha, Chairperson, and Mr. Jonathan Alles, Acting CEO on behalf of Hatton National Bank PLC and Mr Bai Yingfu, general manager of CDB's Guangxi branch and HNB chairperson Ranee Jayamaha.

implementing_agencies: China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd., State-owned Company; Sri Lanka Ports Authority, Government Agency
title: Colombo Port City Project - Phase 1: China Development Bank Loan (link to project ID #55528)
description:
On 16 September 2014, China Communications Construction (CCC) signed the Colombo Port City Franchise Agreement with the Sri Lanka Ports Authority(SLPA), outlining an investment for the Colombo Port City Project (now known as the Colombo International Financial City). On this same day, China Development Bank signed an 805 million USD commercial loan financing agreement with CCC for this project (see attached 2014 article CDB). The 805 million USD loan from China Development Bank for the Colombo Port City Project is captured in this project. For details regarding the equity investment from CCC, see linked project ID #55528. 

On 16 September 2014, China Communications Construction (CCC) signed the Colombo Port City Franchise Agreement with the Sri Lanka Ports Authority, outlining an investment for the Colombo Port City Project (now known as the Colombo International Financial City). On this same day, China Development Bank signed an 805 million USD commercial loan financing agreement with CCC for this project (see attached 2014 article CDB). The equity investment from CCC for the Colombo Port City Project is captured in this project. For details regarding the 805 million USD loan from China Development Bank, see linked project ID #33431.

The Colombo Port City (CPC) Project was initially conceived as a public sector project that would be undertaken by the Sri Lanka Port Authority (SLPA). Consequently, the SLPA commissioned at its own cost an “initial technical feasibility study” in April 2010 for the reclamation of land south of the new breakwater. Around June 2010, an environmental impact assessment study was commissioned by SLPA also at its own cost through the University of Moratuwa (UoM) for a reclamation area of 200 hectares. 

In October 2010, Sri Lanks’s Urban Development Authority (UDA) completed a master plan study based on the initial technical feasibility study and submitted a project proposal to the SLPA for consideration. In April 2011, based on an unsolicited concept proposal submitted by China Communications & Construction Company (CCCC), the parent company of CHEC Port City Colombo (PVT) Ltd., the Government of Sri Lanka (GOSL) decided to not to commit public funds to construct the CPC Project and proceeded to negotiate with CCCC to implement the project entirely as a foreign direct investment, with no financial guarantees by the GOSL on the investment.  

After a 2.5 year period of negotiation with a Standing Cabinet Appointed Review Committee (SCARC) and a Technical Evaluation Committee (TEC) represented by 16 GOSL organizations, a project agreement was entered into between CHEC Port City Colombo (PVT) Ltd., and the Secretary to the Ministry of Highways, Ports and Shipping (acting for and on behalf of the GOSL) on September 16, 2014. CHEC Port City Colombo (Pvt.) Ltd., is a project company (special purpose vehicle) and wholly owned subsidiary of China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC), which operates under its parent company China Communications Construction Company Limited (CCCC). 

The project agreement was signed, and the project’s construction works were ceremonially inaugurated on the same day (September 16, 2014) in the presence of the President of the Peoples’ Republic of China and the President of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, during the Chinese President’s State visit to Sri Lanka.  Colombo Port City (CPC) Project is being implemented on public-private partnership (PPP) project and BOOT basis and it is being financed according to a 70:30 debt-to-equity ratio. 

The $1.396 billion project is divided into two phases: the first phase investment will cost $1.150 billion and the second phase investment will cost $246 million. The first phase was started on September 16, 2014. Its originally planned completion date was April 2020, but construction was suspended due to the change of government in March 2015. Construction then resumed in August 2016. The new expected completion date is April 2024.  

On May 12, 2017, China Development Bank provided a $805 million loan to CHEC Port City Colombo (Pvt.) Ltd. for the first phase of the project, or roughly 70% of the total cost of the first phase project of the project.  The loan carries a 10-year maturity and a 3-year grace period. No sovereign guarantee was provided for the loan. China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) is the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the Colombo International Financial City (CIFC) project. The Chinese project title is 斯里兰卡科伦坡港口城项目. The second phase of the project is also expected to be financed with a debt-to-equity ratio of 70:30. This project is located on reclaimed land adjacent to the Galle Face Green in the city of Colombo. It is between the southern edge of the new Colombo South Port and the Fort Lighthouse. Its locational coordinates are 06°56′00″N 79°50′00″E.

title: Colombo-Katunayake Expressway
description: On 6 August 2009, China Exim Bank signed a 248.2 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway Project. The estimated total cost of the project was 350 million USD, so the Chinese financing accounts for about 70% of the total funding (see Government of Sri Lanka 2017 Bond Prospectus). The loan has an interest rate of 6.3% and a maturity of 16 years, including a 4 year grace period (see 'Global Partnership' document from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). On 18 August 2009, the construction of the 25.8-kilometre-long Colombo - Katunayake Expressway (E03) started. In October 2013, the expressway was officially opened and ready for use. The highway links the capital Colombo with Negombo City, one of the major commercial hubs and major tourist destination in the country. The contract for the project was awarded in August 2008 to the China Metallurgical Group Corporation.

implementing_agencies: China Machinery and Electronic Products Exhibition Centre, State-owned Company
title: Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project (Phase II) (link to projects ID #33244 and #33463)
description: In 2009, EXIM Bank of China committed a US$891 million preferential buyer's credit facility to Sri Lanka's CEB (Ceylon Electricity Board) for Phase II of the Norochcholai Coal Power Project in Puttalam, which is also referred to as the Puttalam Coal Power Project. This loan is a 20 year soft loan with a 5 year grace period and 2% interest. This second phase was implemented in 2010 and completed in 2014. The main components of this project include the establishment of two power plants with a capacity of 300MW each, a transmission line from Norochcholai to Anuradhapura, new substations at Chilaw and Anuradhapura and the construction of the expansion of coal handling port facilities and employees' housing. The project was implemented by China Machinery Engineering Corporation under the supervision of the Ceylon Electricity Board and was to be completed in three phases. Construction of the first phase began in 2007 and was opened on 22 March 2011 (see projects ID#33244 and #33463). The final phase of the project was officially opened on 16 September 2014. According to the 2009 Performance Report from the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources, Phases II & III were implemented together as Phase II due to the urgency of developing low cost power. This plant is sometimes referred to as the Lakvijaya Power Plant. China merchants group owns an 85% stake in this power plant as of 2012.

implementing_agencies: Ceylon Electricity Board, State-owned Company; China National Electric Equipment Corporation (CNEEC), State-owned Company
title: Broadlands Hydropower Project
description: China National Electric Equipment Corporation will be constructing the 35 MW Broadlands Hydro Power Project over the Kelani River at Kithulgala. The total cost of the project is82 million, and was partially financed by a69.7 million loan from the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, and insurance coverage from the China Export and Credit Insurance Corporation. The loan agreement was signed on 16 January 2013 and has a grace period of 3 years and a maturity of 15 years (see 'Resource Mobilization' from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The remaining funding will be supplied by the Hatton National Bank of Sri Lanka. The Broadlands project is the last plant in the so-called Laxapana cascade power station complex on the Kelani River system which was started 50 years ago. The project was due to be complete and connected to the grid by 2014, however construction only began in July 2013. As of August 2015, around 10 per cent of the project was complete. The project was expected to be completed in 2020, consisting of two dams, and a power station further downstream. However, official source (Department of External Resources) reports indicate that the project was completed on January 16, 2018. The project was implemented by the Ceylon Electricity Board, the largest electricity company in Sri Lanka. The completed project had a 24m high & 144m long main dam, a 19m high & 48m long diversion dam, a 2.7m diameter & 850m long diversion tunnel, a 5.4m diameter & 3Km long main tunnel, a 35MW surface power station (2 units of 17.5MW), a switch yard, and a 4Km long transmission line.

implementing_agencies: China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC), State-owned Company
title: Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project (Phase I): Buyer's Credit Facility (linked to #33244 and #33452)
description: On 9 September 2006, China Eximbank signed a USD 455 million financing agreement with Sri Lanka for Phase I of the Norochcholai Coal Power Project in Puttalam, which is also referred to as the Puttalam Coal Power Project (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization' for the commitment date). This financing agreement consists of two components, a USD 155 million buyer's credit facility (not preferential) and a USD 300 million preferential buyer's credit facility (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2009 Annual Performance Report). For the purpose of this project, only details related to the USD 155 million non-preferential buyer's credit facility have been recorded. For details regarding the USD 300 million preferential buyer's credit facility, see project ID #33244. According to the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus, the USD 455 million of Chinese financing covered the total cost of the project. The main components of this project include the installation of a 300MW coal power plant, a jetty for coal handling, and transmission lines from Norochcholai to Veyangoda and substation at Veyangoda. The power plant constructed under the scope of this project is known as the Lakvijaya Power Station or the Norochcholai Power Station (see Sri Lanka Ministry of Power, Energy and Business Development). According to the Sri Lanka Ministry of Power, Energy and Business Development, the USD 155 million buyer's credit facility has an interest rate of 6%. Phase I construction began on 23 July 2007 and was completed in March 2010. The contractor for this project was China Machinery Engineering Corporation. For information on Phase II, see project ID #33452.

implementing_agencies: Aitken Spence (Sri Lanka), Private Sector; China Merchants Holdings (International) Company Limited (CMHI), State-owned Company; Sri Lanka Ports Authority, Government Agency
title: CPEP Phase I Stage II - South Container Terminal One: Debt Component (link to projects ID #54211 and #54212)
description: On 23 September 2011, a consortium led by China Merchants and Sri Lankan conglomerate Aitken Spence PLC signed a deal with the Sri Lankan government worth 500 million USD to build and operate the 'Colombo South Container Terminal' . The total length of quay is 1200 meters, with a designed throughput of 2.4 million TEUs, and can accommodate the world's largest container vessels at 18,000 TEUs. Based on information from IJGlobal Project Finance & Infrastructure Journal, the project's debt-equity ratio is 60:40, with China Development Bank funding the debt portion amounting to 300 million USD. China Merchants Port Holdings, Aitken Spence PLC and Sri Lanka Port Authority provided the 40% equity funding amounting to 200 million USD. The breakdown of the equity funds are as follows: 110 million USD (55%) from China Merchants Port Holdings, 60 million USD (30%) from Aitken Spence PLC, and 30 million USD (15%) from Sri Lanka Port Authority. As described in the attached document from China Merchants Port Holdings, in January 2012 China Merchants Port Holdings acquired Aitken Spence's entire 30% interest, bringing its total equity interest to 85%. China Merchants Port Holdings obtained financing from China Development Bank in respect of this acquisition. For the purpose of this project, only the 300 million USD of funding from CDB has been recorded. For details on the equity portion, please see the linked project #54211, and for details on the purchase of Aitken Spence's 30% interest made by China Merchants Port Holdings, please see linked project #54212. Colombo International Container Terminals Ltd (CICT) is a joint venture between China Merchants Holdings (International) Co. Ltd. of Hong Kong, Aitken Spence PLC of Sri Lanka and Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA). CICT was awarded the tender to construct and operate the Colombo South Container Terminal for a period of 35 years, after which the terminal would be handed over to the Sri Lanka Ports Authority. CMHI initially held 55% interests in CICT while Aitken Spence Plc held 30% and SLPA held 15%. In January 2012, China Merchants acquired Aitken Spence's entire 30% interest in CICT, bringing its total equity interest to 85%. The construction work of the South Container Terminal commenced on 1st December 2011 with the terminal being ceremonially opened for traffic on 8 August 2013. Phase II (Entire Terminal) was completed in April 2014; in April 2014, the completion ceremony of the Colombo South Container Terminal was held.

title: China donates $1.5 million USD to the Defense Service College in Sri Lanka
description: On 30 August 2012 China donated1.5 million USD to the Defense Service College in Sri Lanka, a national school established for children of defense services and police personnel. The donation included funds and materials for a fully fledged laboratory, furniture to the school, fridges, microwave ovens, etc.

implementing_agencies: China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC), State-owned Company
title: Extension of Southern Expressway Section 3 from Wetiya to Andarawewa (also known as Hambantota Hub Development Project) (link to projects ID #38337, #53526, #53522 and #53529)
description: On 16 September 2014, EXIM Bank of China signed a 1,555,990,000 CNY concessional loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Extension of Southern Expressway Project (ESEP) Section 3 from Wetiya to Andarawewa, also known as the Hambantota Hub Development Project. The loan, which covers the total estimated cost of the project, has an interest rate of 2% and a maturity of 20 years, including a 5 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2014 Annual Performance Report). The objective of ESEP is to enhance the efficiency of the transport system by linking the country's major economic centers with Colombo City and other parts of the country. Under this objective, ESEP Section 3 consists of the construction of a 15 km length road section from Wetiya to Andarawewa. The scope of this project includes the construction of 1 viaduct, 18 underpasses, 5 overpasses, 2 bridges, 45 box culverts, and 6 pipe culverts. This project also includes the construction of the Ranna-Wetiya Road (HR 21) and Sooriyawewa-Galwewa Junction-Embilipitiya Road (HR 06, HR 10). The contractor for this project is China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC). ESEP Section 3 commenced on 25 January 2016, and this section has a target completion date of 24 March 2019 (see 'Extension of Southern Expressway' from Road Development Authority). As of 31 December 2018, the expansion was 88.77% complete. The original target completion date was 24 January 2018, but this project is behind schedule due to soil issues and delay in possession of the site. For information on other sections of ESEP, see projects ID #38337 (Section 1), #53526 (Section 2), and #53522 (Section 4). Additionally, China Eximbank provided a loan to fund consultancy services for the expressway (see project ID #53529).

title: China loans Sri Lanka 102.7m USD loan to purchase Chinese S12 power trains
description: 13 new Class S12 power set trains are to be imported from China by. These new power sets were built for Sri Lanka Railways by China's CSR Corporation. The trains were imported under a special loan scheme approved by the Chinese government. The first batch arrived in Sri Lanka in August 2012 and were to replace locomotive-hauled passenger trains. Seven of the S12 DMUs were ordered to strengthen long-distance travel on the Main line from Colombo to Badulla. Four of S12s will serve the Kelani Valley Line. The remaining two designed as luxury trains. In September 2012, the first units had trial runs.The first Main-Line train using the S12 began in 23 October 2012. Sources differ on exact transaction amount. Four different figures were found, all varying quite widely,101 USD million, 9 billion rupees, 13,642 million rupees and lastly 11,900 million rupees. The figure used in the transaction amount is taken from the Sri Lankan Ministry of Internal Transport.

title: China constructs cultural palace in Laos (Linked to Project id #33700)
description: In 2004, China built the National Palace of Culture in Vientiane, Laos. Funds came from a previous 300 million yuan grant and a 690 million yuan credit line that China provided to Laos. The exact amount of the transaction for the National Palace is unknown. Several other projects were completed with the same funds, including a hospital in Luang Prabang (#33700).

title: China assists with construction of hospital in Luang Prabang, Laos
description: As of 2002, China has reportedly built a 100-patient bed hospital in Luang Prabang province. The project was reported concurrently with several other activities. It was mentioned in broader reports that China has granted non-refundable aid worth 300 million Chinese Yuan and a credit of 690 million Chinese Yuan to Laos's key projects. According to the 'New Vientiane' newspaper report in 2002, China has invested USD 120 million in 90 investment projects in Laos. Some of the projects have been put into operation.

implementing_agencies: China Railway Group Co., Ltd., State-owned Company
title: EXIM Bank loan for construction of Kunming-Vientiane high-speed railway link
description: China will loan $480 million for the construction of a 420 kilometer single track electrified Lao-China rail line section from Vientiane to the border with China on the North. The railway line is a section of the proposed Kunming – Singapore Trans Asian Railway corridor. The start of works on the section of the proposed corridor going through China was announced earlier in 2016. The Lao P.D.R. section project has been estimated at US$6.7 billion, out of which 30 percent will be provided by a joint venture company already formed between Lao P.D.R. and China. Lao P.D.R. will need to contribute with 30 percent in the capital of this company (or around US$700 million) in annual installments over the medium term. Out of this, US$480 million will be borrowed from China while the remaining funds will be provided by the Budget. The joint venture company will need to secure the remaining 70 percent of the project costs. Lao P.D.R. Ministry of Finance has noted that no sovereign guarantee will be provided. The grace period is 5 years with a 20 year loan with 2% interest. The formal start of works was announced in December 2015. However, progress has been slow due to still unresolved property issues as well as detailed design works. More recently, six lots for construction works (covering the full length of the proposed railway) were tendered with the awards being given to two Chinese companies with considerable experience in the field. The Lao P.D.R. Ministry of Finance envisages start of construction activities at some point during 2017.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China donates $30,000 for Laos flood relief
description: In 2011, The Chinese government donated 30, 000 U.S. dollars to Laos on Friday [2 September] to help repair damage caused by recent flooding in the wake of tropical storms Haima and Nock-Ten. Chinese Ambassador to Laos Bu Jianguo made the donation at a ceremony held at the Lao Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Laos' capital of Vientiane, attended by Lao Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Sounthone Xayachak.
sources: http://ssc.undp.org/content/dam/ssc/dgspaces/China/files/China%202nd%20White%20Paper%20on%20Foreign%20Aid%202014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://china.org.cn/world/2011-09/03/content_23345898.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020110902e792003xp&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://la.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t857646.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Sounthone Xayachak., Lao Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs; Bu Jianguo, Chinese Ambassador to Laos

funding_agencies: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
title: China Development Bank loan for construction of Laos hydropower project phase 2 (Nam Ou 1, 3, 4, 7) (linked to #35714)
description: In April 2011, Sinohydro signed a deal with the Laotian government to fund a 2 billion USD hydropower project along the Nam Ou River. The two sides agreed to construct seven dams along the Nam Ou river, and the loan agreement was signed by representatives from Sinohydro and Electricite du Laos (EDL). The construction of dams 1, 3, 4 and 7 was to be funded through a $1 billion loan from China Development Bank. No further details on loan. Dam 1 is located in has a total reservoir capacity of 1.18 × 108 million cubic meters and a capacity of 180MW. Dam 3 has a total reservoir capacity of 218 million cubic meters and a capacity of 210MW. Dam 4 has a total reservoir capacity of 142 million m3, and a capacity of 132MW.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: The Chinese government will help Lao National Television (LNTV) to upgrade its technology for Channel 3
description: In 2013, LNTV and China Radio and Television Co. signed an agreement for China to upgrade technology for Channel 3. China has agreed to provide a new video service for broadcasting and an outside broadcast vehicle as the main items of the assistance. They will also provide other pieces of equipment such as router control panels, a broadcast system, optical transmitters and receivers, studio HDV cameras, and sound mixers. Transaction amount is unclear.

contacts: Liu Dongsheng, CRTV overseas department manager; Dr Bounchom Vongphet, LNTV director-general

funding_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
title: Loan for Rebuilding Luang Prabang Airport
description: The Lao Government has borrowed over 570 billion kip (US$57.8 million) from Exim Bank of China to invest in rebuilding Luang Prabang's International Airport. China CAMC Engineering Co Ltd will be responsible for the survey, design and construction of the rebuilding project, expected to be over within 45 months. The reconstruction works include new runway with a length of 2,800m and width of 45m and building two taxiways to access the aircraft hangar of the airport. The development plan also includes the rehabilitation of the hanger to be able to hold four Boeing 737s or ATR 320s.

funding_agencies: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Suzhou Industrial Park Overseas Investment Company, ; Yunnan Construction Engineering Group Corporation (YNJG),
title: China Development Bank loan for construction of sports stadium
description: In 2007, China agreed to build a 94,298 square meters, 20,000-seater sports stadium in Vien Chang for the hosting of the 2009 Southeast Asian Games. It will employ about 3,000 Chinese construction workers to do so. It was completed and opened in 2009. The China Development Bank agreed to provide a concessional loan of US $100 million to build the sports stadium on the surety of a land concession. Construction was conducted by Yunnan Construction Engineering Co. The stadium also includes two 3,000-seater gymnasium and swimming pool, warm-up pool, tennis court, shooting gallery and outdoor training grounds. Sources conflict on the exact transaction amount for this project. The one reflected here is from the Chinese Embassy website.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China supports Laos Bokeo bridge construction
description: By Dec 10, 2013, the 4th Lao-Thai Friendship Bridge in Bokeo opened officially, which the Chinese government helped fund. According to Thai PBS, the bridge was a joint venture between Thailand and Laos, via grant aid. The total cost of the project exceeded $48 million. Deputy Prime Minister of Laos Somsavat Lengsavad, represented the Lao government at the official handover alongside Chinese Ambassador to Laos, Guan Huabing. The amount funded by China is unclear.

contacts: Maha Chakri Sirindhorn, Princess of Thailand; Thongsing Thammavong, Prime Minister; Somsavat Lengsavad, Deputy Prime Minister of Laos

funding_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
title: China Exim Bank loans $308 million for construction of Nam Khan 2 hydropower plant in Laos (linked to project #47140)
description: October 13 2006, Laos and China signed the Memorandum of Understanding for the Nam Khan 2 & 3 hydropower plants. In August 2009, Sinohydro Corporation, China's largest builder of hydropower plants, signed a contract with Laos' electricity supplier, Electricite Du Laos (EDL) to build two hydropower stations and a power transmission line in an enterprise costing $308 million USD according to the Consultative Group for International Agricultural Research. The contracts included the construction of a 230-kV power transmission line from Xieng Khouang to Luang Prabang city, which is the major part of Laos' 2020 national grid network plan. Sinohydro will have an initial ownership of 85% while EDL will have an initial ownership of 15% in the project. The construction cost of Nam Khan 2 hydropower plant was US$308.5 million and has been loaned by the China Exim Bank at an interest rate of 2 percent per year. The duration of the loan is 20 years. Construction on the plant began on November 26, 2011, and is scheduled for completion in September 2015. An impoundment ceremony was held on April 18, 2015. The ceremony was to begin water storage in the reservoir to supply the power plant for electricity generation. This is linked to project #47140, the Nam Khan 3 plant.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Norinco, State-owned Company
title: $103 million loan for construction of Nam Theun 2 Irrigation System
description: The Lao government has financed the project through a bank loan from the Chinese government amounting to more than US$103 million, of which US$31.5 million is for the development of the first tailrace and US$71.6 million is for the fourth tailrace. The US $31.5 million project has been 95 per cent funded by a loan from the Chinese government, with the remaining coming from the Lao government's joint fund. China-based Norinco International is undertaking construction. Irrigation Department Director General, Maykong Phonephommavong, said the project would supply water to 2,700 hectares of rice fields in 10 villages as well as for cash crop plantations and livestock operations. This project is the construction of outlets at the Nam Theun 2 dam to irrigate cultivation land, not the construction of the dam itself. STAFF_NOTE: Details unclear over the $103 million loan; breakdown given only for $31.5 million for the first tailrace.
sources: http://debate-central.ncpa.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/02/China_vs_West_Aid.pdf, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=ANNT000020131104e9b400006&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://wle-mekong.cgiar.org/new-nam-theun-2-outlets-to-serve-agriculture/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://library.opendevelopmentcambodia.net:8080/newgenlibctxt/CatalogueRecords/13_Mehtonen_Myths-of-Mekong.pdf, Academic Journal Article; http://www.mtnforum.org/sites/default/files/publication/files/4948.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2013/11/20/lao-pdr-statement-on-recent-developments-around-irrigation-scheme-utilizing-water-discharged-from-the-nt2-downstream-channel, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: $91.5 million loan for construction of Phongsaly-Yunnan road
description: Work on a new road connecting Phongsaly province to the Chinese border officially began on November 30 2013, with the project expected to boost trade and investment and help the country's socio-economic development. The 142 kilometre Road No. 1A will connect Phongsaly's Bounneua and Nhot-ou districts to the Lantoui international border checkpoint with China and onto Pu-er in Yunnan province. It was expected to take 54 months to complete, though this figure has since been revised in 2014. The project will cost US$91.5 million, 95 per cent of which comes from a Chinese government loan. The remaining 5 per cent will be paid from the Lao government's joint fund.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Chinese Government to Give Loans for the expansion of the Dongmarkkhai water supply project
description: On 4 August 2013, Laos' Foreign Minister Dr Thongloun Sisoulith and his visiting Chinese counterpart Wang Yi held talks on Saturday seeking ways to deepen bilateral ties and cooperation between the two neighbours. On this occasion, the Chinese government agreed to provide loans amounting to more than 725 billion kip (US$92.8 million) for the expansion of the Dongmarkkhai water supply project. As of 2014, the Vientiane Times reports that the project is currently under implementation.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China constructs Agricultural Demonstration Center in Timor-Leste
description: It was reported that the Chinese government is providing technical assistance to the government of Timor-Leste, in the form of advanced technologies and agricultural experts, and the construction of an agricultural demonstration center. However, any further details of the agricultural demonstration center, including its operation, are unclear.

implementing_agencies: Beijing Institute of Architectural Design, Academic, Training and Research
title: China loans 100m RMB for construction of Bangabandhu International Convention Centre (Linked to project #33940)
description: China and Bangladesh signed a loan agreement in which the Chinese government is to provide a 200 million RMB interest-free loan for Bangladesh to build the Bangabandhu International Convention Centre. The total cost of the project was 2 billion takal. The multi-purpose conference center was designed by the Beijing Institute of Architectural Designs and Research and has a construction area of 19,926 square meters. Construction was completed in July 2001. In 2002, China converted a portion of the funding for this project to a grant. The project was renamed Bangabandhu International Convention Centre in 2009. According to Bangladesh's Economic Relations Division, the true loan amount was 100m RMB. 11.099m RMB of this loan was converted to a grant, and the remaining 88.901m RMB has been repaid as of 2017. This project captures the interest-free loan portion; for the grant portion, see project #33940.

implementing_agencies: China National Cable Engineering Corporation,
title: US$74 million in supplier's credit for power grid rehabilitation
description: In 2000, China pledged US$74 million in supplier's credit via the China National Electric Import & Export Corporation (CNEIEC). The CNEIEC and Bangladesh Power Development Board (PDB) had earlier signed an agreement to rehabilitate substation and transmission portions of the Bangladeshi power grid - a project valued at 5.53 billion taka (US$106 million). 29 grid substations and 819 kilometers of 132-kilovolt transmission lines were to be rehabilitated in 36 months, increasing capacity from 1100 to 2000 megawatts. In May 2000, the loan agreement has been signed between CNEIEC and the Economic Relations Division (ERD) under the Bangladeshi Ministry of Finance. The China National Cable Engineering Corporation is the main contractor for this project, and they are responsible for the design, manufacturing, logistics and installations. Construction work started in October 2005. In February 2007, construction was successfully completed and handed over to the Bangladesh Power Development Board.

contacts: Wang Chungui, Ambassador; Song Yueming, President (China National Electric Import & Export Corporation)

title: EXIMbank 1.26 billion CNY in export seller's credit for telecommunications project
description: In 2000, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a loan of 1.26 billion CNY to China Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Co (CMEIE) for a telecommunications project in Bangladesh. The project will upgrade telephone exchange equipment in 58 districts of Bangladesh, which will help promote the country's telecommunications industry. This is the largest sum of export sellers credit the bank has ever granted in one package for supporting the export of telecommunications equipment. Details on the project status and loan details were not found.
sources: http://www.telecompaper.com/news/eximbank-finances-china-machinery-contract--243809, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=scmp000020010816dw7o00hjf&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcape0020010804dw4s000j2&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Conversion of RMB11.099 million loan to grant for Bangabandhu International Convention Centre (linked to project #33925)
description: In 2002, the Foreign Minister of China stated Beijing converted RMB11.099 million out of a total loan of RMB200 million into a grant for the China-Bangladesh Friendship Conference Center. The center, constructed in Dhaka, has been presented to Bangladesh as a gift. The agreement occurred between Foreign Minister M. Morshed Khan and Prime Minister Begum Khaleda Zia's visit to China. The project was renamed Bangabandhu International Convention Centre in 2009. This project captures the grant portion; for the interest-free loan portion, see project #33925.

implementing_agencies: China Road & Bridge Corporation (CRBC), State-owned Company
title: 60 million RMB grant for the 6th Bangladesh-China Friendship Bridge (linked to #39022 and #41981)
description: In January 2002, China committed 110 million RMB (1.29 billion BDT) in grants and loans to build the 6th Bangladesh-China friendship bridge (Muktarpur Bridge) over the Dhaleswari river. Of this funding, 60 million RMB will be provided for as a grant and 50 million RMB as an interest free loan. The bridge is 1,521 meters in length, and 10 meters in width, with one lane for each direction. China Road and Bridge Corporation undertook the construction of the bridge, and the Jamuna Multi-Purpose Bridge Authority was accountable for the project. A groundbreaking ceremony was held on January 27, 2005 and attended by Bangladeshi Prime Minister Khaleda Zia and Chinese Ambassador to Bangladesh Chai Xi. Construction works started on April 28, 2005, and the bridge was completed in January 2008, 7 months ahead of schedule, and inaugurated in February 2008.

title: China loans Bangladesh $87 million to fund paper mill modernisation
description: In May 2001, China committed supplier's credit to Bangladesh for the Balancing, Modernisation, Rehabilitation and Expansion (BMRE) of the Karnaphuli Paper Mills in Chittagong, via the China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC). The BMRE project was intended to expand production capacity, from 37500 metric tonnes to 85500 metric tonnes per year, as well as improve output paper quality of the mill. In 2005, China agreed to convert the supplier's credit into a concessional loan. After having been stalled, the project resumed in 2014, with the loan having been converted again, into a zero-interest preferential loan of87 million. According to a 2017 Report on Suppliers' Credit from the Economic Relations Division of Bangladesh, none of the committed funding has been dispersed as of 2017.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=unibag0020010716dx57002ve&pp=1&fcpil=zhcn&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://erd.portal.gov.bd/sites/default/files/files/erd.portal.gov.bd/page/b09c0301_8d15_49e1_8af9_3231f08b8ad8/Tbl-7.3.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://newsfrombangladesh.net/view.php?hidRecord=55320, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.observerbd.com/2014/12/20/61733.php, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.hawker.com.bd/news_details.php?news_id=390319&news_category_id=6&val_lan=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://bdnews24.com/business/2005/05/20/china-agrees-to-convert-suppliers-credit-into-concessionary-loan-for-bmre-of-kpm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Dr Masihur Rahman, Bangladeshi Economic Relations Division secretary; Q.X Zhang, CMC Mission chief (China National Machinery Import & Export Corperation (CMC))

title: Supplier Credit for Barapukuria Power Plant (Linked to #34237)
description: In June 2001, China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC) and the Bangladeshi government signed an agreement that four Chinese companies (China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation, Shanghai Electric Corporation, China and Shenzhen Energy Engineering Corporation, and Consortium of the People's Republic of China) would provide Taka 1073.36 crore, equivalent to 188.10 million US dollars under supplier's credit to to implement two 125 MW coal power plants in Dinajpur. CMC was awarded the contract by the Bangladesh Power Development Board for the construction of Barapukuria 2X125 megawatts Coal-Fired Power Plant Project in July 2001. In 2002, China and Bangladesh signed an MoU to construct the Barapukuria (Dinajpur) coal fired power plant, consisting of two 125 MW units, implemented and constructed by the China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC). After three years of construction since November 2002, the first unit was successfully put into operation in mid November 2005, and the second in 2006. According to the Suppliers' Credit report from the Economic Relations Division (ERD) of the Bangladeshi Government, 124.126 million of the loan has been repaid as of June 30, 2017.

implementing_agencies: China National Electric Import & Export Corporation, State-owned Company; Post and Telecommunications Ministry, ; TeleTalk Bangladesh, Ltd., State-owned Company
title: China EXIMbank offers concessional loan of 216 million USD to upgrade telephone networks in Bangladesh
description: In September 2006, China pledged a concessional loan to Teletalk, of211 milllion, but the deal expired without any payment in August 2008. In 2009, China pledged to renew the deal. The money was to be used to upgrade Bangladesh's telephone networks to 3G, via Teletalk. TeleTalk, Bangladesh, Ltd. was designated to implement the project under the supervision of the Ministry of Post and Telecommunication. The project will increase TeleTalk's capacity to provide service to 4.73 million new 3G subscribers and 4.77 million new 2. 5G GSM mobile subscribers. Planned completion was July 2010. In October 2012, Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina inaugurated the 3G network. China National Electric Import and Export Corporation would implement the project. According to Teletalk, the project has a loan amount of USD 211 Million with an annual interest rate of 2%, 4 years grace period, 20 year repayment. In December 2010 , Teletalk Bangladesh signed the agreement with CMEC to expand the 2.5G network and to construct the new 3G communications network. The agreement is worth a total of approximately 216 million USD and it will be provided for with concessional loans from the China Export-Import Bank . The contract was enforced on June 9, 2011 and construction works officially started on January 6, 2012.

title: Chinese government gives donation to Bangladesh police
description: In March 2006, China handed over security gear (bullet proof jackets and helmets) to the Bangladeshi police as a gesture of friendship. The handover took place between the Chinese Ambassador of Dhaka, Chai Xi, and Bangladesh State Minister for Home Affairs, Lutfozzaman Babar.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=UNIBAG0020060323e23m0000p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Lutfozzaman Babar, State minister for home Affairs; Chai Xi, Ambassador

title: China donates meteorological satellite receivers to Bangladesh (Linked to #35301)
description: In 2006, China donated Fengyun receivers to Bangladesh (among other countries) to integrate it into the Fengyun satellite system, enabling it to receive signals from weather satellites. The system receives real-time data from Chinese and international meteorological satellites and broadcasts the information to the countries. The satellite network will also serve to better integrate the recipient countries with China. This project is linked to #35301, in which China trained satellite receiver operators.

implementing_agencies: China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC), State-owned Company
title: China grants Bangladesh 60 million yuan to finance Bangladesh-China Friendship Exhibition Center (linked to project ID #54289 and #34069)
description: On 24 April 2008, China and Bangladesh signed a MoU on the construction of Bangladesh-China Friendship Exhibition Center in Dhaka. The center will be the permanent site of the annual Dhaka trade fair, with 806 booths of 9 square meters each, and 1500 open-air parking lots. On January 20, 2017, China State Construction Engineering Corporation won the construction bid worth 380 million Yuan. The project's expected completion date is December 2020. The Chinese government signed two different deals to finance the construction of the exhibition center. In 2008, the Chinese government pledged to provide 2.1 billion BDT of the estimated 2.75 billion BDT needed for the project. According to Bangladesh's Economic Research Division's Commitment and Disbursement of Grants for 2016/17, the Chinese government allocated 60 million RMB for the project. As of 2017, 9.7 million Yuan of the total allocation has been dispersed. According to a press release by the implementing company, on April 17, 2017, the Bangladeshi side officially handed over the land permit and coordinate control map to the Chinese side, symbolizing the formal handover of the entire project site and allowing the construction to go further. On July 10, 2018, the Bangladesh Economic Commission Executive Committee (ECNEC) officially approved a modification to the project. The total project cost increased from 2.75 billion BDT to 7.96 billion BDT, and again to 10.03 billion BDT. The government of China agreed to send additional financing, bringing the total Chinese contribution to 6.26 billion BDT. This project only captures the initial 60 million yuan grant from 2008. For the 2018 modification, see project ID #54289. This project was announced at the same time as a 0.5 million yuan unallocated 'token grant' described in project ID #34069.

title: China to donate $1 million USD in emergency assistance to Bangladesh following cyclone Sidr (Linked to #34165)
description: On November 9, 2007 Chinese Ambassador to Bangladesh Zheng Qingdian pledged 1 million USD for Bangladesh's relief and rehabilitation activities following cyclone Sidr. The donation was completed.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Zhejiang Sifang Group Corporation, State-owned Company
title: China commits to agricultural machinery factory project
description: In May 2000 Chinese Minister for Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangsheng and Myanmar's Minister at the Office of the Chairman of the State Peace and Development Council Brigadier-General Abel signed an agreement for China to build an agricultural machinery factory in Mandalay. The Chinese government extended a 144.88 million yuan interest-free loan for construction. The factory was built on 25000 square meters and should annually produce 10000 sets of horsepower and 5000 sets of 3.5 HP reaper. China was responsible for design, supervision of civil engineering, supply and installation of equipment, technical training while Myanmar was responsible for civil engineering. The Zhejiang Sifang Group of China completed the factory in December 2003 and formally handed it over to Myanmar on December 20, 2003.

title: China opens Narandi China Friendship Center in Bangladesh
description: The Chinese government donated the Narandi China Friendship Center, a cultural center based in the Northern Bangladeshi village, Narandi. The center is designed to be a vocational center for children, complete with technology and reading resources. The cost of the center is unclear. The center includes a computer room, a library, an auditorium and an entertainment center. All of the 10 computers and some books at the center were also donated by China. On October 18, 2018, the site was visited by Chinese ambassador Zhang Zuo. A Xinhua report claims that the library will contain Chinese magazines and a collection of Chinese books including: Mao Zedong on Diplomacy, Islam in China, and China Sports. This center operates on 81 thousand square meters of land. Narandi village is 80 km north of Dhaka. STAFF_NOTE: This project is coded as having both representational and development intent, since the education programs also promote Chinese culture.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: China Metallurgical Construction Corporation - Capital Engineering & Research Incorporation, Ltd. (MCC-CERI), State-owned Company
title: China extends seller's credit to build the Thabaung pulp mill
description: On July 16, 2000 the China Metallurgical Construction Group and Myanmar Paper and Chemical Industries signed an agreement for construction of the Thabaung pulp factory in the Ayeyarwady region. The factory has a capacity to produce 200 tons of pulp daily, to substitute imports of pulp. Construction began on November 1, 2001 and was inaugurated by Prime Minister Soe Win in May 2005. China extended 90 million USD in seller's credit for the project. The factory was inaugurated on 14 May 2005.
sources: http://en.people.cn/200112/26/eng20011226_87515.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcape0020010804dw7h00130&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=lba0000020010820dw7h01mte&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://mm.china-embassy.org/chn/sgxw/t195777.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.caexpo.org/gb/biz/business_guide/policy/t20050517_39781.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_chn/gjhdq_603914/gj_603916/yz_603918/1206_604498/1206x2_604518/t437111.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.xinhuanet.com/world/2005-05/14/content_2958669.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://mm2.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/chinanews/200505/20050500095228.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.burmalibrary.org/docs07/NLM2009-08-13.pdf, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ibiblio.org/obl/docs2/PULP.pdf, Academic Journal Article
