implementing_agencies: China Petroleum Engineering & Construction Corporation (CPECC), State-owned Company
title: China Exim Bank loans 1.1 Billion USD to Atyrau Refinery LLP for deeper oil refining complex (Linked to project #54797)
description: On June 6, 2012, Atyrau Refinery LLP entered into a U.S.$1.1 billion loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the construction of a deeper oil refining complex This loan is secured by China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (SINOSURE) and bears interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 4.1% per annum and matures on 6 November 2025. The loan is guaranteed by the Company. As at 31 December 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was U.S.$1.1 million. It is highly likely that this project was funded through the 3 billion USD restricted portion of a China Eximbank Master Loan Facility to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, captured in #54797.

implementing_agencies: China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering And Construction Co.,ltd. (NFC), ; Kazakhmys, Private Sector
title: China Development Bank Aktogay copper deposit RMB Facility (Linked to Project ID #41941)
description: In December 2011, CDB signed two bilateral agreements with Kazakh Copper Company (Originally called Kazykhmys PLC, now called KazMinerals) to set up loan facilities worth 1.5 billion to for copper mine development projects in Aktobe. Aktobe maintains a volume of 5 million tons of copper. The money was used to construct Aktogay mine. First copper cathode production from oxide ore occurred in December 2015, whilst first copper in concentrate output from sulphide ore began in February 2017. The main sulphide concentrator was constructed by Nonferrous China (NFC). The project capital cost is expected to be in the region of2.1 billion. The mine is expected to produce up to 100,000 tons of copper concentrate annually in 2015. On February 16, 2012 the loan was finalized and signed as two transactions one for RMB 1 billion (158 million), the other for 1.34 billion USD. It is being developed as an open-pit mine including an on-site concentrator and construction work started in the first half of 2013. The Facility has a final maturity of 15 years from the date of first drawing. The total Aktogay Facility of approximately1.5 billion is comprised of two separate agreements, a USD agreement for up to1.34 billion and an RMB agreement for up to RMB 1.0 billion (approx158 million). Both agreements are reportedly on essentially similar terms and conditions, except that proceeds drawn under the RMB agreement can only be applied towards payments to Chinese suppliers for equipment, materials and services sourced from China. The interest rate on the USD agreement is set with reference to USD LIBOR, while the RMB agreement is at the applicable benchmark rate published by the People's Bank of China (PBoC). The maturity period for the loan is 15 years, and the grace period is 3 years. In the KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016, the interest rate is stated to be 5.12%.

implementing_agencies: China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), State-owned Company; KazTransGas, State-owned Company
title: China loan syndicate funds the development, construction and operation of the Bozoi-Shymkent part of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline (link to #40362)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP was established in the Republic of Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas and China National Petroleum Corporation each have 50% ownership stake in Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP.  The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline is a 1454 km long gas pipeline that will run through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern regions of the Republic of Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of the Republic of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases. 

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 and completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 6 bcm per year.  It involved 1143.2 km of pipeline construction from the Bozoy gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe oblast to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam region of South-Kazakhstan oblast. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe oblast, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in Kyzylorda oblasts and an emergency-response center in Shornak within South-Kazakhstan oblast, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas ppeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South-Kazakhstan oblasts. 

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was completed on December 30, 2016. It involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau oblast to Bozoy settlement in the Aktobe oblast. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in Kyzylorda oblast, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau oblast, the SCADA central dispatch control  in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South-Kazakhstan oblasts. Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, which increased the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas deliveries to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of 5 billion cubic meter of natural gas (bcm) during the period from 15 October 2017 until 14 October 2018. 

The price of gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement is linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. Negotiations are ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expects the transportation of gas to China to increase in the coming years and, in order to facilitate such transportation, plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019.

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 million syndicated loan with China Development Bank and Bank of China on December 11, 2012 (Project ID#39562). This loan bears interest at a rate of three-month LIBOR plus 2.7% per annum for the duration of the guarantee period and, thereafter, at a rate of three-month LIBOR plus 3.2% per annum. The loan matures on 11 March 2028. The loan is secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP then signed a $700 million syndicated loan with China Development Bank and Bank of China for Phase II of the project on September 17, 2015 (Project ID#40362).  CDB and Bank of China each reportedly contributed $350 million. This loan reportedly carries a 15 year maturity; however, the interest rate of the loan is unknown.

This 1454 km pipeline runs through runs through the territory of Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South-Kazakhstan oblasts. The first phase of the project (Project ID#39562) involved 1143.2 km of pipeline construction from the Bozoy gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe oblast to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam region of South-Kazakhstan oblast. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe oblast, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in Kyzylorda oblasts and an emergency-response center in Shornak within South-Kazakhstan oblast, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas ppeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South-Kazakhstan oblasts. The second phase of the project (Project ID#40362) includes 306.3 km gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau oblast to Bozoy settlement in the Aktobe oblast. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in Kyzylorda oblast, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau oblast, the SCADA central dispatch control  in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South-Kazakhstan oblasts. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/

implementing_agencies: Tebian Electric Apparatus, Private Sector
title: China loans Kyrgyzstan $389.795 million USD for construction of Datka-Kemin power transmission line and Kemin substation (Linked to Project #40431)
description: The agreement to construct a power line was agreed to sometime in 2010. On June 5, 2012, China and Kyrgyzstan signed an agreement to construct a national power transmission line from Datka to Kemin and a substation in Kemin, Kyrgyzstan. The preferential credit agreement of 389.795 million USD was ratified by the Kyrgyz law on June 19, 2012. The construction of the line and substation began in 2012 and ended in 2015, with the inauguration of the transmission line occurring on September 1, 2015. The loan was financed by the Chinese EXIM Bank, and the line and substation were constructed by the Tebian Electric Apparatus company after an agreement with the National Electric Network of Kyrgyzstan. According to the Kyrgyz Republic AMP,344,373,400 USD (88%) of the total committed amount was disbursed as of 2015. This is probably linked to project #40431.

implementing_agencies: Tebian Electric Apparatus, Private Sector
title: China loans 386 million USD for modernization of Bishkek Thermal Power Plant
description:
On September 11, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Kyrgyz Republic’s Ministry of Finance signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2013) 38 TOTAL NO. (282)] for the Bishkek Thermal Power Plant Modernization Project. The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.25% commitment fee, and 0.18% management fee.  

The proceeds from this loan were to be used to finance a commercial contract (number D-166-21/322) between the Joint Stock Company (JSC) “Electric Power Plants of Kyrgyzstan” and Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA). This project sought to install two turbines (units 12 and 13) with a capacity of 150 megawatts at the Bishkek Thermal Power Plant (TPP). As a result, the capacity of Bishkek TPP was expected to increase by 125 megawatts. Prior to project completion, the annual output of electricity at the TPP was one billion kWh. After its modernization through the China Eximbank-financed project, the production of the TPP was expected to reach 1.8 billion kWh. Heat production was also expected to increase from two million gigacalories to three million gigacalories per year.  The project began implementation on April 26, 2014 and it was successfully completed on August 30, 2017. 

However, this project was plagued by controversy. In 2015, the Chamber of Audits, a state body tasked with overseeing government spending, issued a report questioning why the TBEA contract was not put out to tender when other companies were interested in bidding. Auditors also found that no technical feasibility study was undertaken to evaluate the needs and costs of the project. Nurlan Omurkul, who was chief of the Bishkek TPP, said that he had harbored strong doubts about hiring a company with no track record of building power stations, but that he had been badgered by senior Kyrgyz officials to endorse a decision that he said had obviously already been made. He told the New York Times that “I’ve worked my whole life in power and heating plants and knew all along that the Chinese price of $386 million was too expensive.” Another Chinese company, China Machinery Engineering Corporation, offered a lower bid, $356 million, according to a parliamentary commission. But the Chinese Embassy reportedly insisted that its offer be dismissed. Eventually, the country’s former Prime Minister (Jantoro Satybaldiev), former mayor of Bishkek (Kubanychbek Kulmatov), and former Energy Minister (Osmonbek Artykbaev) were arrested on corruption charges and accused of using their positions to lobby for the interests of a Chinese company (TBEA) in the selection process of the contractor for the project. Prosecutors in the case claimed that rigged bidding and inflated pricing would cost the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic as much as $111,252,797. 

Staff Note: The Bishkek TPP is also known as the Bishkek Combined Heat and Power Plant (CHP).  The Chinese project title is 比什凯克热电厂改造项目.

implementing_agencies: Tebian Electric Apparatus, Private Sector
title: EXIM Bank loans 309,592,800 USD for North-South power transmission line
description:
In March 2006, the Government of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a MoU for projects proposed by Tajikistan (see pg. 14 of 'China as an Emerging Donor in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan'). Later that year, on December 21, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $267,219,451 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project (see pg. 37 of 'Consolidated financial statements...'; for the transaction amount, see pg. 87 of 'Power Utility Financial Recovery Program-for-Results (P168211) Program Technical Assessment Final Report'). The loan terms carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see 'List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018'). The initial estimated value of the project was $281.3 million USD (see pg. 32 of 'Tajikistan Policy Notes on Public Expenditures'). 

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend (through subsidiary loan agreement (No. BLA06015, #6015) to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 21, 2006 and June 21, 2026. As of December 31, 2018, $2,519,773 USD was outstanding (see pg. 37 of 'Consolidated financial statements...'). OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of 'Consolidated financial statements...').

The purpose of this project was to construct a 500 kV electricity transmission line that would connect the northern Sughd region to the national grid (see pg. 32 of 'Tajikistan Policy Notes...'). According to Xinhua, the project also intended to realize the effective dispatching of electricity between Dushanbe and Khujand, completely solve the problem of power shortage in the south during the dry season in winter, build the transmission channel for the implementation of the Tajik Hydropower Strategy, improve the safety, stability, and reliability of the power grid, and reduce the loss of electricity through transmission from 14% to 3.2%.

Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for project implementation (see pg. 11 of 'BRI in Central Asia: Energy Connectivity Projects'). Construction began on September 16, 2006, after a ceremony attended by Wen Jiabao and President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, according to the Chinese Embassy. The North-South transmission line has been operational since November 29, 2009, according to TBEA. The construction of transmission line reportedly enabled Tajikistan to become independent of the Uzbek power transmission network and to distribute electricity throughout the country (see pg. 11 of 'BRI in Central Asia...').

For additional financing for this project, see project ID#70910. For another power transmission project that also received additional financing, see project ID#39984.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство ЛЭП 500 кВ “Юг-Север”. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克斯坦南北220—500kV输变电成套工程. Additionally, China Eximbank indicates that this project was financed by preferential export buyer's credit in the '重大项目 Major Projects' document.

title: China EXIM bank provides 100 million CNY loan to Uzbekistan for 2500 tractors
description: In November 2001, China's EXIM Bank and the Pahkta Bank of Uzbekistan signed a soft credit agreement for 100 million CNY to purchase 2,500 tractors from China. The loan is for 10 years with a 3 year grace period and an interest rate of 4%/yr. The tractors will be produced by Zhongce Tractor and Motor Vehicle Co. Ltd and delivered by China Tianjin Machinery Import and Export (Group) Co

implementing_agencies: China International Trust and Investment Corporation (CITIC), State-owned Company
title: ICBC loans $29.2 million for Kungrad Soda Ash Plant in Uzbekistan (linked to #54832)
description:
In 2003, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) signed a $29.23 million export buyer's credit loan agreement with Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank) for the construction of the Kungrad Soda Ash Plant in Uzbekistan within the autonomous republic of Karakalpakstan. The loan carried an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.5%. Sinosure provided insurance. CITIC Group and Uzkimyosanoat were responsible for project implementation. Under the terms of its contract, Citic Pacific Ltd. designed and constructed the plant on a turnkey basis (in which CITIC would turn over the plant after a certain number of years of its operation) at a cost of $32.3 million. The plant was officially commissioned in August 2006.  This project sought to achieve a production capacity of 100,000 tons of soda ash per year  — by mining limestone from the Jamansay (Dzhamansay) quarry and the Barsakelmes field salt field in Karakalpakstan (an autonomous republic in north-western Uzbekistan). The main consumers of soda plant are Uzbek enterprises that produce household chemicals and building materials, including various types of glass. Then, in 2012, the capacity of the plant was expanded to 200,000 tons per year, which was partially financed by a loan from China's Eximbank (see Project ID #54832). 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 乌兹别克斯坦昆格勒纯碱厂.

title: China grants 5 seismological stations worth 300K USD
description: In 2003, China Seismological Bureau gave 5 seismological stations that worth 300,000 dollars to the Uzbek Academy of Sciences. This aid is based on an agreement signed between these two parties in 2001. China also sent specialists to provide the assistance with setting up and using the equipment. Four of these stations were installed in Tashkent, and one was installed in central Uzbekistan. This donation aims to modernize Uzbekistan's capacity to register and study earthquakes.

title: China offers 50 million yuan interest-free loan to Uzbekistan in developing agriculture
description: Summary: In May 2004, The Uzbek foreign minister and the Chinese ambassador to Uzbekistan signed a credit agreement under which China would offer 50m Chinese yuan of interest-free loan. The document was signed by Uzbek Foreign Minister Sodiq Safoyev and the Chinese ambassador to Uzbekistan, Gao Yusheng. Under the document, the Chinese side will send agricultural machinery and computer equipment. The loan would be used for five-year projects to be implemented as part of bilateral relations.

implementing_agencies: Tebian Electric Apparatus, Private Sector
title: China's Exim Bank loans 63,855,200 USD to Tajikistan for construction of Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line
description: In April 2006, China's Exim Bank provided a 63,855,200 USD preferential loan to Tajikistan for the construction of the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line in Khatlon province. The loan has a 2 percent interest rate, 5 year grace period, and 20 year maturity. The total cost of the project is 66.7 million USD, with Tajikistan paying for the remainder. China's Tebian Electric Apparatus will construct the 93 km Lolazor-Khatlon line for Tajikistan's Barqi Tojik (Tajik electric systems). Construction began in 2006 and was completed in June 2008. The Lolazor-Khatlon line has a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year and it will also allow for the exporting of electrical power to Afghanistan. China Eximbank also provided loans to Tajikistan for the North-South power transmission line (see Project ID #39644) and the Khujand-Ayni transmission line (see project ID #40051). STAFF_NOTE: Several sources refer to the preferential loan facility as 55.2 million USD and the total cost of the project as 58 million USD. The Tajikistan AIMS indicates that the commitment from China Eximbank was 63,855,200 USD for this project, and a case study from the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific indicates that the total cost of the project was 66.7 million USD.

implementing_agencies: China Road & Bridge Corporation (CRBC), State-owned Company
title: China Exim Bank loans 281.1 million USD for Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak road construction
description: In March 2006, a memorandum of understanding was signed which identifies the financing project of implementation of 1st stage of the Dushanbe--Khujand-Chanak highway in Tajikistan. The Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak highway project started in July 2006. According to the agreement, the China Road and Bridge company was to reconstruct the 354km highway connecting Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan, with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. It is expected that the works will be finished by August 2010. The total cost stood at 295.9 million US dollars. The loan portion was financed by EXIM Bank of China at281,105,000 through 4 annual disbursements. The loan has a 20 year repayment period, 5-year grace period, and 2 percent annual interest rate. The project includes the construction of the Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of88,424), the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. The project began in July 2006, and was expected to be completed in 2008. It was completed in 2010.

title: Line C of Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, Kazakhstan section (linked to #40833, #39955, #54489)
description:
The Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, which is also known as the China-Central Asia Gas Pipeline, is a 1,873-km gas pipeline that connects Turkmenistan to China via Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan. It consists of 4 lines (A/B/C/D), with A,B,C parallel to each other. The pipeline starts at Gedaim on the border of Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, runs through central Uzbekistan and southern Kazakhstan, and ends at Horgos in China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. Line A (#40833) of this pipeline became operational in 2009 while the other two lines — Line B (ID #40834) and Line C (ID #39997) — started their operations in 2010 and 2014, respectively. Line A and B will be connected to the Second West-East Gas Pipeline, while Line C will be connected to the Third West-East Gas Pipeline. Line D (#39955) runs through Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan to Wuqia County in China, where it will be connected to the Fifth West-East Gas Pipeline. Line A, B, and C are providing 55 billion cubic meters of gas to China per annum, while Line D is still under construction. There are segments of each line constructed within Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, and Kyrgyzstan 

This project records the financing of the Kazakhstan segment of Line C. Construction of Line C began on January 16, 2013. The line went into operation on May 31, 2014. Line C was officially commissioned on July 9, 2015.  Line C successfully transmitted gas to Khorgas on June 15, 2017.  With a designed capacity of 25 billion cubic meters per annum, Line C’s pipe diameter is 1,219mm, 152mm larger than Line A/B. The overall welding work of the pipeline was completed at the end of 2013. Upon completion of all supporting facilities of Line C by the end of 2015, the overall delivery capacity of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline will reportedly reach 55 billion cubic meters per annum. This equals to approximately 20% of China’s annual natural gas consumption, and would substitute 73 million tons of standard coal, cutting carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide emissions by 78 million tons and 1.21 million tons every year, respectively.  JSC KazTransGas formed a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) with CNPC (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) called Asia Gas Pipeline LLP (AGP) to construct and operate the Kazakhstan-China Gas Pipeline. JSC KazTransGas and CNPC each hold 50% equity stake in AGP. 

In December 2012, AGP entered into a U.S.$4.7 billion syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank and Bank of China for the purposes of financing the construction of line C of the 'Kazakhstan-China' pipeline. Amounts borrowed under the facility accrue interest at a rate of three-month LIBOR plus a 2.35 percent margin during the guarantee period and three-month LIBOR plus by 3.45 percent margin per annum thereafter. The borrowed amounts must be repaid starting from June 2017 until 27 December 2027. The loan is secured by a 'ship or pay' transportation agreement pledge, account charges, insurance and reinsurance policies assignments and guaranteed by CNPC. As at 30 June 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $3.3 million. According to this information, the interest rate is recorded as 3-Month LIBOR in December 2012 (0.309%) + 2.35%; grace period = 4.5 years; repayment period = 10.5 years, maturity period = 15 years.

Line C of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline (also known as the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline) is 1830 km in length. It starts at the Turkmenistan-Uzbekistan border and ends at Horgos, in the Xinjiang region of China. This loan supported the Kazakhstan section of Line C.

title: EXIM Bank offered preferential loan to Fiji for Moto road upgrades #40003 #40006 #40007
description: SUMMARY On October 4, 2013, one of the four rural road upgrading projects supported by Chinese government, Moto Road, Fiji was successfully completed. The project was funded by Exim Bank of China in the form of preferential loans and was implemented by China Railway First Group Co,. Ltd. The actual paid loan was 22.620 million USD. The project started on Jan 12, 2012. This is a multi-year project. Buca Bay Stage 1 (10km reconstruction and fill including the replacement of 2 bridges) - 82.5% complete. Stage 2 - (20km of reconstruction and fill including the replacement of 3 bridges) - 42% complete. Moto Road (5km of reconstruction and fill including the replacement of one bridge) - 95% complete. Progress was delayed by materials issues. The higher than originally estimated local share cost is principally for contract escalation (up until April/May 2013) that it had earlier been understood would be able to be funded from the loan.Project ID linked to ##40003 #40006 #40007

implementing_agencies: Tebian Electric Apparatus, Private Sector
title: China Exim Bank loans 35,055,000 USD for Khujand-Ayni power transmission line
description:
On November 25, 2010, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed credit agreement No. N0.2010 (024) TOTAL N0. (131). In it, Eximbank agreed to provide the Tajik Ministry of Finance with a $35,055,003 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 220 V Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project (for commitment date, see 'ORDER OF THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN of October 4, 2013 No. 445'; for loan amount, see 'May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS China Specific Projects'). The PBC loan carried the following terms: a 20 year maturity, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and 2% interest rate (see 'List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018'). The project had a total value of $36.9 million USD (see pg.32 of 'Tajikistan Policy Notes on Public Expenditures').

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend to OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” (through a subsidiary loan agreement -- No. 2010 (024) TOTAL (170) – 029 BT) at a 3% interest rate between December 15, 2010 and September 21, 2031 (see pg. 37 of 'Consolidated financial statements...'). OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of 'Consolidated financial statements...'). 

The project involved the construction of a 118 km, 220 kV transmission line from Khujand to Ayni, according to Asia-Plus. The transmission line also involved the construction of the Ayni and Shakhristan substations. The Khujand-Ayni power transmission line was intended to connect the Zarafshon Valley to the unified power system through the 500 kV South-North power grid (see pg.32 of 'Tajikistan Policy Notes on Public Expenditures'). The line was an opportunity to address the power supply problem in the Zarafshon Valley and reduce northern Tajikistan's dependence on energy from Uzbekistan. Chinese company TBEA was the contractor responsible for project implementation, according to Asia-Plus.

The groundbreaking ceremony, attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, was held on July 8, 2010. The power transmission line was expected to be finished by the 20th anniversary of Tajikistan’s independence, on September 9, 2011, according to Asia-Plus. The transmission line was put into operation on September 26, 2011, in a ceremony attended by President Rahmon, according to Asia-Plus.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство высоковольтной линии электропередачи 220 кВ «Худжанд - Айни». The AIMS project ID is TJK/112014.

implementing_agencies: China Road and Bridge Corporation, State-owned Company
title: China Exim Bank loans $49m USD for Dushanbe-Dangara road reconstruction [Phase 1] (linked to ID #53750, #40440)
description: In 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China loaned Tajikistan 49 million USD for Phase I of the rehabilitation of the Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma road. This 154-km road between Dushanbe, Vakhdat, and Dangara is the first phase of the 1,100 km Tajikistan-China highway project. The total cost of this project is51,578,000 with the remainder funded by the Tajik government. This section of the road is 57.8 km, and the project was implemented from 2009-2012. This project is linked to project ID #53750, an Exim bank loan for Phase II of the project, and #40440, an Exim bank loan for the Chormagzak tunnel as part of the Phase II project.

title: China grants Uzbekistan 3.7 million USD for customs checkpoint upgrades
description: On February 10, 2009, China and Uzbekistan governments signed off on a grant of 25 million CNY (3.7 million USD) at the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations, Investments, and Trade (MFERIT) in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. The agreement was signed by Minister of Foreign Economic Relations, Investments and Trade, Elyor Ganiyev, and Chinese ambassador to Uzbekistan, Yu Hongjun. The grant is for equipment for customs post and mobile x-rays in order to prevent smuggling and boost trade.

implementing_agencies: China National Chemical Engineering Corporation (CNCEC), State-owned Company
title: China EXIM Bank loans 36 million USD for construction of water pipeline in Uzbekistan
description: In November 2007, China National Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd., China Exim Bank, and Uzbekistan signed a contract worth 44.97 million USD for the construction of a water pipeline in Uzbekistan. China Exim Bank provided a loan of 36 million USD, and the rest of the funds will be contributed by the Suvokava (Vodokanal) Company. The total cost of the project would be 48.3 million USD. Exim Bank's loan would be for 20 years with a 5 year grace period and 2% interest rate. The project is to construct the improvement of potable water supply at 100,000 cubic meters per day, a number of booster pump stations, and a big-caliber 120-km water transmission pipeline for the Uzbek cities of Fergana, Margilan, and Andizhan. The construction was reported as completed as of November 30, 2011. STAFF_NOTE: Sources reported different loan amounts provided by China Eximbank; transaction amount coded as36 million because this was the more conservative amount and reported by the IMF.

title: China Exim Bank loans Uzbekistan 177.6 million USD for purchase of oil rig equipment
description: In mid 2007, Uzgeoburneftegaz (Uzbekneftegaz subsidiary) signed a contract with China Petroleum Technology & Development Corp to supply 23 drilling rigs as well as with China National Machinery Industry Corporation to supply 10 cementers. In September 2009, China Petroleum Technology & Development Corporation and China National Machinery Industry Corporation (SINOMACH) delivered 23 drilling rigs, four cranes, and 10 cementing units that worth209.1 million USD. China Exim Bank loaned 177.6 million USD with a 15-year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 3.5% interest rate to purchase the equipment. 31.5 million USD will be funded by Uzbekneftegaz.

description: On June 21 2010, China delivered 22 tons of humanitarian aid to Uzbekistan, including food, blankets, generators, mobile showers, and medications. The value of this donation was 3 million RMB. This aid would ease the strain on Uzbekistan to resettle refugees fleeing unrest in Kyrgyzstan's Osh region.

implementing_agencies: Zhouzhou Electrical Locomotive Works,
title: China loans Uzbekistan $70.11m for purchase of Chinese electric locomotives
description: In November, 2007, China and Uzbekistan signed MOU which pledged to offer Uzbekistan concessional loans for purchasing electric locomotives from China. The contracted was signed in May, 2009. In 2010, Uzbekistan Temir Yollari state joint stock railway company received three electric locomotives, which were made by China Zhuzhou Electrical Locomotive Works. Uzbekistan Temir Yollari received electric locomotives within the agreement with Zhuzhou Electrical Locomotive Works. In line with the document, the Chinese company would supply 15 electric locomotives. The Uzbek company received first two locomotives in June 2010. The Chinese company planned to supply other 10 by the end of 2010. The cost of the project is75.53 million USD, which is financed due to loan of China for70.11 million USD and own funds of the Uzbek railway company for5.42 million USD. Loan funds are provided for 20 years, including a five-year grace period, at a rate of two percent per annum. The project speed of the electric locomotives makes up 160 km per hour, which would allow to double passenger turnover at the electrified railway roads of Uzbekistan. New equipment will be used on railway lines Samarkand - Khojidavlet and Navoi - Samarkand.

description: On Wednesday June 9, 2010, the China Exim Bank agreed to loan Uzbekistani commercial bank, Uzpromstroybank. The Uzpromstroybank will use the loan specifically to modernize the Angren coal mine in Tashkent. The loan is part of a larger 154 million USD economic cooperation agreement between China and Uzbekistan. The loan terms are unknown

title: Exim Bank commits $172 million USD for locomotives in Kazakhstan
description: On December 31, 2002 the Export-Import Bank of China committed172 million to be provided to the Kazakh railroad for 14 years at 5.3% annually without government guarantees, according to company President Yerlan Atamkulov. Kazakhstan Temir Zholy planned to buy locomotives from Chinese plants and assemble them in the city of Chou (Dzhambulsk region).

title: China donates 1million yuan worth equipment to Kazakh police
description: On February 19, 2003 China's Public Security Ministry donated police equipment to the Kazakh Interior Ministry in Almaty. The total cost was 1mil yuan. The police equipment and technology supplied by China includes night vision devices, metal detectors, microscopes, tape recorders, computers, scanners, printers, photo equipment, telephones and flashlights. The agreement on the supply of special equipment by the Chinese Public Security Ministry as technical no-strings aid to the Kazakh Interior Ministry was signed by the sides in Beijing on November 18, 2002.

title: China EXIM Bank loans Uzbekistan 70 million USD for gas network construction
description: In June 2010, China Exim Bank and Uzpromstroybank signed a loan agreement for 70 million USD to modernize the gas distribution network in Uzbekistan during the state visit of the Chinese President Hu Jintao to Uzbekistan. The loan will be used for introduction of the system on management and technologic communication of gas transport network (SCADA) worth 77.4 million USD, extending the system with 2,000 km of fiber optic line.

title: China donates 5 million RMB for Kazakhstan training of state personnel
description: In March 2006, China signed an agreement to finance 5 million RMB for projects funding training for state personnel in Kazakstan. The agreement was signed by the chairman of the State Service Agency, Zautbek Turisbekov, and the Chinese Ambassador to the RK Zhang Siyun.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KAZAEN0020100620e23e000hh&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Zhang Siyun, Chinese Ambassador to Kazakhstan

title: China Donated $500,000 grant to Uzbekistan for earthquake relief
description: In July 2011, the Chinese Government pledged to provide the Government of Uzbekistan with a500,000 grant for emergency relief after an earthquake. On December 26, 2011, Chinese ambassador Zhang Wei and Uzbekistan’s Deputy Minister of Finance Jorkin Tulsonov signed an intergovernmental transfer certificate for the Uzbek government’s500,000 foreign exchange humanitarian assistance project in Tashkent.
sources: http://uz.chineseembassy.org/chn/zwgx/jmhz/t890436.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/200905/20090506214789.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=CEASEN0020110729e77t000xd&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks

implementing_agencies: CITIC Construction Group, State-owned Company
title: China EXIM Bank loans Uzbekistan 42 million USD to construct phase 2 of Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant (Linked to Project ID #40129)
description: On September 22, 2011, China's EXIM Bank and Uzpromstroybank Uzbek Joint Stock Industrial Construction Bank signed a loan agreement for 42 million USD to build the second phase of the Dehkanabad potash fertilizer plant. The funds are under guarantee by Uzbek government and drawn from Chinese government reserves for SCO members. The loan has been issued for 20 years with a 5 year grace period, but with no specified interest rate. CITIC Construction was responsible for the construction. The project will also be funded by FRD (62 million USD) and Uzkimyosanoat (22 million USD) for a total of 126 million USD. The second phase construction is meant to triple capacity - up to 600,000 tons of potash/year, 350,000 tons of which is planned to be exported.
sources: http://www.uzbekembassy.org/userfiles/files/files/Fund%20of%20Reconstruction%20and%20Develpment.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=IXCENT0020110923e79m000p2&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201011/20101107248686.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://uz.chineseembassy.org/chn/zwgx/jmhz/t839131.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=TRENDE0020110922e79m0040h&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks

implementing_agencies: China CITIC Construction, State-owned Company
title: China EXIM bank loans Uzbekistan 41.7 million USD for construction of phase 1 of Dehkanabad potash plant (linked to ID #40128)
description:
In 2007, China Eximbank provided a $41.705 million loan to Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank) for Phase I of Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant Project. The terms of the loan are as follows: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. This project involved the construction of the Dehkanabad potash plant located at the Tyubegatan deposit.  

Construction of phase 1 of the plant started in 2010. The total cost of the project is $123.7 million. In addition to the China Eximbank funding, the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan allocated a $61.9 million loan, and Uzkimyosanoat also directed its own funds to finance the construction. This project sought to increase the capacity of the plan to produce 200,000 tonnes of potash per year. In 2008, SJSC Uzkimyosanoat concluded contracts with ZAO UK Zapadouralsky Machine-Building Concern (Russia) and CITIC Pacific Ltd. (China) for the turnkey construction of the facility. Construction began in 2007 and the first phase of the project was completed on October 5, 2010. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 乌兹别克斯坦钾肥加工厂. The Russian project title is xСтроительство ДЗКУ 1-очередь. Plans are in motion to triple the production capacity to 600,000 tons per a year. This project is linked to Project ID#40128, a second China Eximbank loan for Phase II of Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant Project.
sources: http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/dl/gbdqzn/upload/wuzibieke.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.uzdaily.uz/en/post/1693, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.uzdaily.com/articles-id-17598.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.uzbekembassy.org/userfiles/files/files/Fund%20of%20Reconstruction%20and%20Develpment.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.uzdaily.com/articles-id-17598.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=IXCENT0020110923e79m000p2&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201011/20101107248686.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

implementing_agencies: China National Technical Import & Export Corporation, Government Agency
title: Exim Bank loans $42.75 million USD for the purchase of freight locomotives
description: In December 2011, Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC signed a contract with a consortium consisting of China National Technical Import & Export Corporation, CNR Dalian Locomotive and Rolling Stock Co. for the purchase of 11 freight locomotives. China's Exim Bank would fund this transaction with a loan of42.75 million USD, with Uzbekistan Railways funding the remaining2.2 million USD. This loan from the Exim Bank would have a 20 year maturity with a 5 year grace period and an interest rate of 2.25%. The delivery of the three electric locomotives was completed in 2013, and the rest of 8 locomotives was delivered in 2014. Staff_Note: Transaction amount was changed from 42.17 to 42.75 according to source from ECCO.
sources: http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201402/20140200501559.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://uz.chineseembassy.org/chn/zwgx/jmhz/t1069497.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://en.trend.az/casia/uzbekistan/2474143.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/news/asia/single-view/view/electric-freight-locomotives-unveiled-in-toshkent.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://uzbekistan.org/news/archive/1162/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.railjournal.com/index.php/locomotives/cnr-completes-delivery-of-locos-to-uzbekistan.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=TRENDE0020111221e7cl0028l&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.thecaspiantimes.com/uzbekistan-receives-electric-locomotives-from-china/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201302/20130200021971.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China EXIM bank loans Uzbekistan 37.1 million USD for construction of high voltage line
description: In January 2012, Uzbekenergo and China Exim Bank agreed to cofinance construction of a high voltage power line costing 83.5 million USD total, with Uzbekenergo contributing 46.4 million USD and Exim Bank contributing 37.1 million USD. The loan is given for 20 years including a five-year grace period. Uzbekenergo will construct the 500 kV power transmission line by 2012 and planned completion is 2014.
sources: http://www.timesca.com/index.php/news/7390-chinas-eximbank-issues-loan-to-uzbekenergo-for-building-transmission-line, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=KAZAEN0020120127e81r0000p&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.timesca.com/news/10175-uzbekenergo-to-build-835m-power-line-with-chinese-help, Media Report, including Wikileaks

implementing_agencies: China IPPR International Engineering Corporation, State-owned Company
title: Chinese Government grants $5.9 million for pump equipment and reconstruction of Karakul pump station in Bukhara oblast
description: In 2008, the Chinese government provided a grant of5.9 million to Uzbekistan for the purchasing of pump equipment for the pumping station 'Karakul' reconstruction in Bukhara oblast. In July 2011, China's IPPR International Engineering Corporation signed a contract with the Uzbekistan government for purchasing equipment for the Karakuli Pumping Station. This project will increase the water supply capacity of the pumping station to 45 cubic meters per second, and the energy consumption of the unit will be greatly reduced. The total cost of the project was7.2 million, and the Ministry of Agriculture provided the rest of the funding for the project. In August 2012, China's IPPR International Engineering Corporation completed construction of the Karakul Pumping Station to ensure uninterrupted water supply in the area. STAFF_NOTE: Some sources have Chinese grant amount as7.3 million, but transaction amount was recorded as5.9 million as this is the more conservative amount and the one reported by the IMF.
sources: http://www.timesca.com/news/7242-chinas-ippr-to-reconstruct-a-pumping-station-in-uzbekistan, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=TCASIA0020120905e88t0000q&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/CR/Issues/2016/12/31/Republic-of-Uzbekistan-Poverty-Reduction-Strategy-Paper-21636, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201301/20130100005684.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Development Bank loans Uzbekistan 220 million USD for thermal plant rehabilitation
description: On October 22, 2012, Uzbekenergo State Joint Stock Company (SJSC) secured a loan from China Development Bank worth 220 million USD to co-finance a project to update Tashkent's Thermal Power Plant. The loan is under government guarantee for 15 years with a 3 year grace period. The interest rate was equal to six month LIBOR rate plus 3.6% APR (with an average six month LIBOR rate of .687 % for the year of 2012). A 370 MW steam-gas installation will be built. The total project is for 511.8 million USD, and will also be financed by Uzbekistan's Reconstruction and Development Fund (76.2 million USD), a business loan from Synecta a.s. (68.9 million USD), Uzbekenergo (117.7 million USD), an Uzpromstroybank credit (26.9 million USD), and a credit from Japan International Cooperation Agency (2.037 million USD).
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=TCASIA0020121102e8b100009&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-document/81523/45306-001-rrp.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.uzdaily.com/articles-id-20607.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=TRENDE0020121022e8am003e9&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cdm.unfccc.int/filestorage/v/x/D8CI2BGOZA1MVPN9453HJYLR6SKE0X.pdf/PDD__Tashkent_v.2.1_-_20-03-clean?t=ZDN8bzF4amxlfDCnGlU-5TsaMB_q43-N41mZ, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.jura.lt/en/news/5168-uzbekistan-gets-220-mln-credit-from-china-development-bank-for-modernization-of-tashkent-combined-heat-and-power-plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Development Bank loans $50 million USD to Uzbekistan for high tech park
description: In November 2011, the State Development Bank of China and National Bank of Uzbekistan for Foreign Economic Activity signed a loan agreement for50 million USD to create a high tech park in the Jizzakh region of Uzbekistan. Deputy Minister for Foreign Economic Relations, Investments and Trade of Uzbekistan Shavkat Tulyaganov confirmed this at the Uzbek-Chinese Business Forum in Tashkent on March 31, 2012 and stated that construction would begin in the first half of 2013. The projects will be financed by both China Development Bank's loan and by Uzbek partners, although it is unclear whether the Uzbek funding is part of or in addition to the50 million USD loan.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=UZBDAY0020120331e83v0002y&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gutenberg.us/articles/Economic_development_zones#Jizzakh_high-tech_industrial_park, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

implementing_agencies: Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Private Sector
title: Exim Bank Finances $34M in Export Credits for Huawei Tech Eqmnt for Kazakhstan
description: In 2007, the ExIm Bank of China financed a 7 year,34 million export credit for Kazakhstan to import telecommunication equipment from Huawei Tech. It is reported as having a very flexible payment schedule, but no further details. The primary recipient is Kazakh company Mobile Telecom Service LLP.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=RIAORE0020071115e3bf0030f&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=WDAN000020071115e3bf0000v&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.kase.kz/news/show/1036055, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: China grants 396,000 USD in equipment for Kazakh Police
description: In 2007 the Chinese Ministry of Public Security provided aid worth 396,000 dollars to the Kazakh Ministry of Internal Affairs. The donation included equipment for Kazakh police.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020070720e37k000um&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Grants 31 Buses Worth 10 Million Yuan to Tajikistan
description: In July 3, 2000, on the eve of President of China Jiang Zemin's official visit to Tajikistan, 31 buses were dispatched to Dushanbe from China. The buses had been provided under free technical aid (10m yuans). An official ceremony for handing over the buses was 4th July, with the participation of the Chinese government's official delegation.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcsue0020010804dw7400614&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

implementing_agencies: China Water Resources and Hydropower Construction Corporation,
title: CDB loans 200 million USD for Moynak Hydropower Plant
description: In 2006, alongside a host of other agreements, the Chinese Development Bank granted a200 million USD loan to the Kazakh government for the construction of the Moynak Hydropower Plant. Construction on the plant had started in 1985 but stopped after the collapse of the Soviet Union; thanks to the Chinese loan, in 2006, construction on the power plant started anew. It is located approximately 200km from Almati, along the Charyn River in Almaty Province, and was scheduled for completion in 2009 - it was ultimately commissioned in December 2011, with it being scheduled to operate at full capacity in Spring of 2012. According to the 2012 Bond Prospectus from the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, DBK's participation in the Moynak hydroelectric power plant project was 68.3 million USD. A joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called JSC Moynak HES was set up to manage the loan and the project. This JSC was jointly established by China Water Resources and Electric Power Corporation (CWE), China Geological Engineering Corporation (CGC) and China Hydropower Consulting Group Chengdu Survey and Design Institute (CHIDI) (see attached resource from China's Ministry of Commerce).
sources: https://chinaperspectives.revues.org/4053, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0900R_-2012-11-14.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zhhz/201009/20100907161953.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www1.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/sehk/2011/0621/00847_1099895/e125.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.upi.com/Business_News/Energy-Industry/2009/03/27/Analysis-Kazakhstans-hydroelectric-potential-attracts-foreign-investment/86451238190422/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://investkz.com/en/journals/49/377.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.tj/en/news/kazakhstan-asks-china-development-bank-invest-us-75-million-more-moinak-hpp, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moinak_Hydro_Power_Plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KAZAEN0020110925e48c00ahv&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China grants Turkmenistan 15 million RMB for mechanical plant (linked to project #40169)
description: On Dec. 26, 2003, State officials of China and Turkmenistan signed an agreement for a grant of 15 million RMB (1.8 million USD) and an interest-free credit of 30 million USD (see project #40169). The grant was to be used by Turkmengaz to purchase equipment and spare parts for its repair mechanical plant. Current project status is unknown.
sources: https://www.turkmenistan.ru/ru/node/16078, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1347027.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=4&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0ahUKEwits-GHjorLAhUB2GMKHZWQDN4QFggvMAM&url=http%3A%2F%2Fneurope.eu%2Farticle%2Fchina-finance-turkmen-oil-and-gas-complex%2F&usg=AFQjCNHWFersAQkhZ9ZiddFjqS3WT8-KRw&sig2=1kx9_yyqTN6BU0c2cYN_5w, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020031225dzcp001md&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020031228dzcs000dx&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=TASS000020031226dzcq003ml&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.turkmenistan.ru/ru/node/16072, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=DAIPER0020031226dzcq000jh&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

contacts: Lu Guicheng, Chinese Ambassador

title: China loans interest-free 30 million RMB for mechanical plant (linked to project ID#40168)
description: On Dec. 26, 2003, State officials of China and Turkmenistan signed an agreement for an interest free loan of 30 million RMB ($3.6 million USD) and a grant of 15 million RMB (see project #40168). The loan has a maturity of 20 years. The funding was to be used by Turkmengaz to purchase equipment and spare parts for its repair mechanical plant. Current project status is unknown.

title: China commits 42 million RMB for hospital construction in Osh
description: In May 2012, China and Kyrgyzstan ratified an agreement for the construction of a hospital in Osh. The Chinese originally offered 700 million USD to finance a slew of projects in Osh but ultimately granted 42 million RMB for the construction of the hospital complex, as part of an agreement in May 2012. The Kyrgyz Deputy Minister of Health at the time proposed the grant offer to a Kyrgyz Parliament subcommittee on social affairs. In 2018, the Chinese officers visited the progress of the construction of the hospital.
sources: http://www.kabar.kg/eng/regions/full/1675, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kg.mofcom.gov.cn/article/todayheader/201810/20181002795763.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.donors.kg/images/docs/reports_and_studies/HLC.DOCUMENT.ENGLISH.FINAL.PDF.edited_for_website_en.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.refworld.org/docid/560b8e474.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.akipress.com/news:522772, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kg.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201303/20130300054046.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Liu Zhun, Deputy head of Ministry of Commerce of China; Jusupjan Jeenbekov, First Deputy Director General of the State Directorate; Taalai Sabirov, Vice Mayor; Chjen Shengli, Representative of the Embassy of China in the Kyrgyz Republic; Karyev [卡里耶夫], Deputy Minister of Health, Kyrgyzstan

implementing_agencies: China Road & Bridge Corporation (CRBC), State-owned Company
title: China EXIM Bank provides 129.8 million USD export credit for Rehabilitation of Osh-Batken-Isfana 127km section and Bishkek-Balykchy 25km section
description: On April 1, 2013, the Kyrgyz Parliament approved China EXIM Bank's preferential buyer's credit for the renovation of two roads in Kyrgyzstan. The agreement was signed December 4, 2012 and was worth 129.8 million USD, with a 20 year maturity, an interest rate of 2%, and a grace period of 9 years. The funds would help the renovation of the 127 km of the Osh-Batken-Isfana road and 25 km of the Kuaka-Balykchy road (assumed to be the same as Bishkek-Balykchy road). In 2015, the Kuaka-Balykchy road renovation was finished. China Road and Bridge Corporation commenced construction of the project in July 2013. They reported on their website that the length of the Osh-Batken-Isfana road being rehabilitated is 123.06km, and the length of the Bishkek-Balykchy road being rehabilitated is 23.66km. They also reported that this project is the third China Eximbank financed project in Kyrgyzstan that they undertook. According to the AMP of Kyrgyzstan,32 million of the total pledged value was distributed in November 2013 and the same amount was distributed December 2014.64.9 million USD has let to be undispersed.
sources: http://kg.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201304/20130400075532.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kg.china-embassy.org/chn/dssghd/t1283949.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://amp.gov.kg, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/zrj0yfnwejus6nv/JICA%20Presenta, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/wjb_663304/zzjg_663340/dozys_664276/gjlb_664280/3185_664332/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.developmentcheck.org/projects/729, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China provides free petroleum aid
description: Summary: On April 25, 2000 Shi Guangsheng, Chinese Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation met with Nyam-Osorin Tuyaa, visiting Mongolian minister of external relations to sign documents on China's free petroleum aid to Mongolia. The aid was given as part of a relief package after heavy snow caused a state of emergency in Mongolia. The amount of the aid package is unclear and there are no sources confirming the aid reaching Mongolia.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=xnews00020010818dw4p01pes&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.people.cn/english/200004/26/print20000426_39717.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Mongolia uses bulk of 45million RMB aid package from China to build military housing
description: Summary: In December 2001, the Mongolian government has decided to use most of the Chinese aid to build apartments for military personnel. The 38m renminbi yuan allotted for the housing project was part of a 45m renminbi aid package provided by Chinese government during the seventh meeting of the inter-government committee between China and Mongolia, which was held in Beijing in July. With the implementation of the project, 300 new apartment houses will be built between 2001 to 2003. There is no indication the apartments were ever constructed.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=bbcapp0020011205dxc500461&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=bbcapp0020011221dxcl005v5&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China postpones Mongolian 28.3mil roubles debt
description: Summary: On June 27, 2002 Chinese minister of foreign trade and economic cooperation, Shi Guangsheng, and Minister of Industry and Trade of Mongolia Ch. Ganzorig decided to postpone Mongolia's debt worth 28.3m convertible roubles to China belonging to 1958 and 1960 for another 10 years.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=bbcapp0020020628dy6s002bd&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Sent 15 Million Yuan Worth of Food Aid to Tajikistan
description: In March 2003, China sent Tajikistan 15 million yuan (approximately two million dollars) worth of food aid as part of a humanitarian relief package. The food aid included sugar (2340 tons), rice (1200 tons) and soybean oil (320 tons). The May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS reports a food aid worth1,812,000 USD funded by Chinese government. The project ID is TJK/042050.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020030313dz3d0005r&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tj.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200305/20030500093181.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0, Other

title: China Grants $700,000 Worth of Aid to Tajik Police
description: In March 2003, Tajikistan Interior Ministry received no-strings aid totaling 700,000 dollars from Beijing, China. The aid was received under an agreement signed between the Tajik Interior Ministry and the Chinese Public Security Ministry. Twenty patrol cars (One source suggests 50 vehicles), special equipment, computers, laser printers, uniforms and footwear for the ministry's special subdivisions, special crime detection equipment, communication devices, night vision binoculars, cameras, metal detectors, shields, helmets and many others things were received. The Chinese ambassador to Tajikistan, Mr Wu Hongbin, and the first deputy interior minister, Police Lt-Gen Abdurahim Qahhorov, visited the Interior Ministry's department for the provision of materials and equipment. According to the Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS as of May 2018 reports donation of Policemen facilities worth483,600 funded by the Chinese government, and an additional contribution of157,040 for 'different equipment.' These two donations together total640,640, therefore it seems they are referencing this same project, even though transaction amounts differ slightly. The transaction amount has been coded as 640,640 USD to reflect this official source information.
sources: http://reliefweb.int/report/tajikistan/china-gives-tajikistan-2-million-dollars-food-aid, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0, Other; http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1102748.html, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020030312dz3c003ej&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcca00020030311dz3b000b7&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Abdurahim Qahhorov, first deputy interior minister; Wu Hongbin, Chinese ambassador to Tajikistan

title: China commits to provide mobile inspection systems to Uzbekistan for customs procedures
description: On July 25, 2013, Uzbekistan and China signed an exchange note on implementation of the project on supply of mobile inspection complexes to equip customs posts of Uzbekistan with the grant of the Government of China. The signing ceremony was held at the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations, Investment and Trade. Minister of Foreign Economic Relations, Investment and Trade of Uzbekistan Elyor Ganiev and Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of China Zhang Xiao signed the document. The project included supply of mobile inspection complexes, their assembly and commissioning at the border customs posts, and training of employees of the customs services.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=UZREPE0020130726e97q000b5&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=CEASEN0020130727e97q00003&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://uz.chineseembassy.org/chn/zwgx/jmhz/t1061884.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Zhang Xiao, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of China; Elyor Ganiev, Minister of Foreign Economic Relations, Investment and Trade

implementing_agencies: KazMunayGas, State-owned Company; Sinopec International Petroleum Service Corporation (SINOPEC),
title: China Eximbank funds construction of a complex for the production of aromatic hydrocarbons at the Atyrau oil refinery (linked to project #54797)
description: On July 30 2010, Development Bank of Kazakhstan and Atyrau Oil Refinery (100% KazMunaiGas Exploration and Marketing subsidiary) signed an agreement for the 'Construction of a complex on aromatic hydrocarbons production at Atyrau Oil Refinery in the size of USD1,063,660,000 for 13 years. It is known that on October 29, 2009 under the project Atyrau Oil Refinery signed an agreement with Chinese Sinopec Engineering for construction of the aromatic hydrocarbons production complex. At this, 85% of an agreement cost is funded through the loan of Development Bank of Kazakhstan and Chinese Export-Import Bank. It is highly likely that this project was funded through the 3 billion USD restricted portion of a China Eximbank Master Loan Facility to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, captured in #54797.
sources: http://en.tengrinews.kz/markets/China-allocates-over-1-billion-for-construction-of-advanced-10624/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KASTOK0020100802e67u00004&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KASTOK0020100802e67u00004&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.bu.edu/pardeeschool/files/2016/05/Fueling-Growth.FINAL_.version.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://www.law360.com/articles/369206/kazakh-refinery-lands-298m-in-financing-from-jbic-group, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://www.hydrocarbons-technology.com/projects/atyrau-refinery-modernisation-project/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://rusmininfo.com/news/07-06-2012/atyrau-oil-refinery-plant-signed-loan-agreement-exim-bank-11-bln-construction-advanc, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=EIUCP00020091217e5c70000m&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

implementing_agencies: China National Machinery Industry Corporation, State-owned Company
title: China Exim Bank loans Uzbekistan 300 million USD for PVC plant construction
description: In 2013, China Exim Bank provided a loan of300 million for the construction of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plant at the Navoiazot chemical complex in Uzbekistan.The estimated cost of this project was initially470.8, but was increased to501.1M in 2015.65.9 million in financing comes from the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan as loans, and61.4 million came from Uzkhimprom's own resource. This plant is to have the capacity to produce 100K tons of PVC, 300K tons of methanol, and 75K tons of caustic soda each year. The implementation period of this construction is 3 years, and its implementation is to start in December 2015. The Chinese company CAMC is the contractor of this construction. STAFF_NOTE: One source (Asaka Bank) reported the amount of the Eximbank loan as373.83 million, but for this project the more conservative transaction amount was recorded. Loan details are unknown.
sources: http://www.sohu.com/a/300900847_659458, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.uzdaily.uz/en/post/24953, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=CEASEN0020131003e9a3000rt&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sohu.com/a/300900847_659458, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.camce.com.cn/cn/xwzx/gsxw/201505/t20150504_59541.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.eurasianbusinessbriefing.com/navoiazot-gets-300m-eximbank-loan-for-new-pvc-plant/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://easttime.info/news/uzbekistan/china-has-provided-loan-uzbekistan-construction-new-plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.asakabank.uz/en/cooperation/project_financing, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China provides 5 million RMB grant to Mongolian provinces because of severe winter
description: On February 26, 2003, Ambassador Huang Jiakui of China met the chairman of the State Emergency Commission, Defense Minister J. Gurragchaa, and informed him that China decided to grant 5 million Yuan of aid to the Bulgan, Hovsgol, Tov and Selenge provinces suffering from the severe winter.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=bbcapp0020030226dz2q0053e&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Granted $19,000 Worth of Aid to Tajik Emergency Ministry
description: Summary: On September 20, 2004, Chinese ambassador to Tajikistan, Wu Hongbin, presented humanitarian aid to the Tajik Ministry of Emergency Situations. The humanitarian aid consisted of tents and children's clothing. The total value of the aid is 19,000 dollars. Officials from the Tajik Ministry of Emergency Situations expressed their gratitude to embassy officials for this no-strings aid. The aid provided would be used in the event of natural disasters.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASIPLU0020041006e09k0008g&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020040921e09l001p5&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Wu Hongbin, Chinese ambassador to Tajikistan

title: China Grants $6M to Fight Poverty in Tajikistan
description: Summary: In 2004, China donated nearly 6 million dollars to neighboring Tajikistan to help fight poverty in the Central Asian nation. Mountainous Tajikistan has a 520-kilometer (325-mile) border with its huge eastern neighbor. The two countries inaugurated their first border crossing for vehicles, goods and people in May.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020040726e07q000xe&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AFPR000020040726e07q007nb&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Donates $1,500 to Give 2870 Textbooks to Two Schools in Tajikistan
description: In August 2004, The Chinese embassy in Tajikistan donated 2,870 textbooks in Russian to two secondary schools in Dushanbe. 2,870 textbooks worth 1,500 dollars had been given to school number 51 and the presidential school.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASIPLU0020040826e08i0001p&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020040818e08i0008e&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

implementing_agencies: CITIC Construction Group, State-owned Company; KazMunayGas, State-owned Company
title: Bank of China loans $232 million USD for proposed road bitumens production plant at the plastics plant in Aktau
description:
On September  28, 2010, Bank of China Ltd. signed a $232 million loan agreement with JV Caspi Bitum LLP for the construction of a bitumen (asphalt) plant in Aktau. The proceeds of the loan are meant to cover 80% of the cost of the bitumen (asphalt) plant. JV Caspi Bitum LLP is a project company (special purpose vehicle) that established in October 2009 to assume responsible for the financing, design, and implementation of the Bitumen Asphalt Plant Construction Project. Its owners are Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries JSC (50%) and CITIC Kazakhstan LLP (50%). JSC NSCC KazStroyService and CITIC Construction were contractors responsible for project implementation. Construction began on June 9, 2010. The official commissioning of the plant took place on December 12, 2013. A project completion ceremony then took place on December 20, 2013.

This bitumen asphalt plant is located in the city of Aktau. It is based at the former Aktau Plastics Plant.
sources: http://investkz.com/en/journals/76/619.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KAZAEN0020100929e69t0000a&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KAZWIR0020100929e69s000xe&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kz.chineseembassy.org/rus/zhgx/t710297.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kazakhembus.com/content/kazakh-president-visits-china-deals-worth-23-billion-signed, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.kmg.kz/upload/corporate_management/equity/2013/god2013eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://astanatimes.com/2014/01/bitumen-plant-commissioned-aktau-creating-another-link-china-kazakhstan/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://uc1bf25c866be68e5ee73a595e25.previews.dropboxusercontent.com/nativeprint?file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dropbox.com%2Fs%2Fgvxafjn32lses2g%2F2013%2520Bond%2520Prospects%2520for%2520Kazakhstan%2520State-Owned%2520Gas%2520Company.pdf%3Fdisable_range%3D1%26from_native_print%3D1%26preview%3D1 , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
