title: Chinese universities provide 100 Tajik students with education for Central-Asia Line-D natural gas pipeline project (Lined to project #39955)
description: On October 10, 2017, Xi'an Shiyou University of China held the launching ceremony of the 'Hundred Talents Program' that provides the 5-year training of 100 Tajikistan students for the Central-Asia Natural Gas Project (#39955). The first thirty students to receive the training were selected from the 1000 top students, with the assistance of National Testing Center of Tajikistan, and China National Natural Gas Pipeline Co., Ltd., under the approval of the Deputy Prime Minister of Tajikistan. The students will take Chinese language courses in Tianjin University for one year, and in Xi'an Shiyou University for another year. Then they will study the undergraduate major courses of oil and gas storage and transportation in Xi'an Shiyou University. After graduation, they will work as professionals for the Line D of Central-Asia Natural Gas Project. Fifteen students out of thirty received scholarships of the 'Silk Road' Program from the Chinese government. China-Central Asia natural gas pipeline Line D is an inter-governmental project signed by China, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Kyrghyzstan. The construction of the Tajikistan section of the 1,000-km-long line was launched in September 2014. Of all countries the pipeline travels through, Tajikistan has the longest section of about 410 km. For details on this project see #39955.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNHA000020171011edab000ma&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://xyl.xsyu.edu.cn/xxxw/6457.jhtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China to provide 70 million RMB technical assistance to Tajikistan
description: In 2017, China committed to grant technical facilities worth 70 million RMB to Tajikistan to strengthen its capacity of emergency response. Committee of Emergency Situations and Civil Defense secured automobiles, munitions, and special technical equipment from China through an agreement under the United Nations Development Programme. More than 100,000 people live in danger areas in Tajikistan, and 27 people have died in natural disasters in the first half of 2017. As of July, 2017, 284 areas in Tajikistan were considered dangerous for human habitation. Along with the project, the Committee will also receive500,000 grant from Japan and460,000 from Russia.
sources: http://www.xinhuanet.com//english/2017-07/21/c_136460396.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.osce.org/programme-office-in-dushanbe/386510?download=true, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China agrees to build an industrial zone in Osh
description: In 2017, a Chinese delegation from China's Shaanxi Province arrived in Kyrgyzstan's Osh region. An agreement was signed that allowed for the construction of an industrial zone in the Kara-Suu district. It is unknown how this project is being financed, or what Chinese firms signed this agreement to do the construction.

implementing_agencies: Kyrgyz Border Services, Government Agency
title: China offers technical assistance to Kyrgyz's Border Service
description: In 2017, China's Ministry of Public Security agreed to provide technical assistance worth 1 million yuan to the Kyrgyz Border Service. This agreement was signed in context of strengthening cooperation between the two countries in the fields of counter-terrorism and personnel support. China additionally proposed training cooperation between Chinese and Kyrgyz personnel.

implementing_agencies: China Road and Bridge Corporation, State-owned Company
title: China assists in Rehabilitation of Bishkek roads (Asphalt paving)
description: In December 2017, the Chinese Ambassador to Kyrgyzstan signed letters of exchange with Kyrgyzstan's Minister of Economy for asphalting the pavement of 23 streets with a total length of 38km as well as carrying out road rehabilitation. Media reports note that the total project will cost 278.73 million yuan to execute. The project is implemented by China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) on a grant provided by the Chinese government. According to a press release by the implementing company, the project started construction May 25, 2018. According to a news report on August 26, 2018 by Xinhua News, a Chinese state media outlet, the project had been underway at that time and parts of the road network had been finished. The same report says that the project utilizes a grant from the Chinese government, and is scheduled to be finished by November 2019. STAFF_NOTE: This project should not be confused with project #52924, as CRBC reported #52924 in 2 phases, but reported this project as a stand-alone project.

funding_agencies: China Ministry of Commerce, Government Agency
title: China Constructs School in Bishkek
description: In 2017, the construction of a general school was completed in Bishkek after the China Ministry of Commerce funded the school. The mayor of Bishkek met with Minister Czen Huacheng to thank him for completing the construction of the school. STAFF_NOTE: It is unknown when the two parties agreed to construct the school.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CEASEN0020170731ed7v000jh&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Grants $32 million to fund irrigation projects
description:
On September 11, 2015, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed an agreement providing a $32 million grant for the Agricultural Irrigation Reconstruction Project. This grant will be used to renovate irrigation systems in Kyrgyzstan. The contractor for the project is PowerChina Huadong. Implementation of the project began on May 3, 2018, with an opening ceremony at Issyk Lake (the site of Irrigation District #3). In attendance were President Gehnbenkov, Chinese Embassy Business Counsellor Sun He.

The Irrigation System Rehabilitation Project has three main components: construction of a 16.4 km new irrigation canal and a 29.9 km extension of an existing irrigation canal in Batken district; construction of a 21.3 irrigation canal in the village of Kara-O within the Issyk-Kul region; and reconstruction of the 19km Ak-Olen canal in the Tonsky District. Power Construction Corporation of China (PowerChina) is the contractor responsible for project implementation. On May 3, 2018, project construction began. The project will reportedly put 5410 hectares of new irrigated lands into operation, increase the supply of water to ​​22100 hectares of land, and create jobs for 40,000 rural residents.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 灌溉系统改造工程.
sources: https://24.kg/english/83571__32_million_to_be_spent_on_reconstruction_of_irrigation_system_in_Kyrgyzstan/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CEASEN0020170110ed1a00105&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.xinhuanet.com//english/2017-05/25/c_136314184.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://water.gov.kg/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=644:prezident-sooronbaj-zheenbekov-v-issyk-kulskoj-oblasti-dal-start-realizatsii-proekta-rekonstruktsii-irrigatsionnoj-sistemy-kyrgyzskoj-respubliki&Itemid=1437&lang=ru, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kabar.kg/eng/news/china-is-the-main-investor-for-kyrgyzstan/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China grants $18.3 Million Inspection Equipment for Customs of Uzbekistan
description: In May, 2017, China signed an intergovernmental agreement to grant customs inspection equipment worth18.3 million to Uzbekistan. The equipment include four large-sized inspection and examination complexes and ten sets of scanning systems in Chukursay Railway Station. China will also carry out the installation and maintenance of the equipment and the training of the specialists. On August 3, 2018, the handover ceremony was held.

title: China Exim Bank loans 328.45 M RMB for 113 coaches to Ministry of Railway Transport
description: In 2007, the China Exim Bank provided a 328.45 million RMB loan to to Turkmenistan to purchase 113 railway passenger cars. The loan was given to the Ministry of Railway Transport of Turkmenistan. As of 2012, the loan was still be implemented, according to an annual report from Turkmenistan. STAFF_NOTE: The two book sources cite another book for the loan. However, upon looking at the book, the parent material doesn't offer any new information about the loan. The annual reports and the books record slightly different transaction amounts, however it can be assumed that these are referring to the same project.

title: $300 million CDB loan for oil refinery
description: This refinery is a major industrial undertaking in Kara-Balta, Kyrgyzstan, and will play a key role in promoting local economic development, increasing fiscal income to the government, and improving local employment. The construction has a total investment of USD431 million and the Bank had disbursed USD 300 million in loans by the end of 2015. The project is implemented by a Chinese company, Zhongda. The oil refinery is expected to produce 800,000 tons of fuel annually.

title: $129,825,916 China Eximbank loan for the rehabilitation of road section sin Jalal-Abad and Batken.
description: China Eximbank loaned129,825,916 to Kyrgyzstan for the rehabilitation of road section sin Jalal-Abad and Batken. At present, earthworks and drainage works, as well as repairs with the broadening of 5 bridges, are almost completed. In addition, the laying of the bottom layer of asphalt concrete pavement over 19 km has been completed. The amount of implementation is more than 27.66 million or 30.24% of the contract value. funding_agencies: China Export-Import Bank, State-owned Company
implementing_agencies: China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC), State-owned Company; Pakistan National Highway Authority, Government Agency
title: China pledges business concessional loan of USD361.22 million to Pakistan for Karachi-Lahore highway (Sukkur-Multan Section) (linked projects #39013 and #54416)
description:
On April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Sukkur-Multan Section of the Karachi–Lahore Motorway Project: a $361,224,000 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, an RMB 4.8 billion government concessional loan (GCL) agreement, an a $1,790,113,000 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The BCL loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54415. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#39013. The PBC agreement is captured in Project ID#54416. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are BCL-16MWAY-CPEC, GCL167576-CPEC, and PBC1610398-CPEC, respectively.  

The Karachi–Lahore Motorway (KLM) is a 1,694 km (1,053 mile), six-lane, high-speed, limited-access motorway that connects Karachi and Peshawar through Islamabad, Lahore, Multan and Sukkur. It is considered to be a major component of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). The 387 km, six-lane Sukkur-Multan section of the motorway follows the left bank of River Indus and it involved the construction of 100 bridges, 468 underpasses, 991 culverts, 11 interchanges, six pairs of service areas, five pairs of rest areas, and 24 toll stations. A revised feasibility study was completed for this project on June 18, 2014. China State Construction and Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 5, 2016, and the project was completed on November 5, 2019. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 头实施的白沙瓦至卡拉奇高速公路木尔坦至苏库尔段（PKM项目). The Multan-Shujabad section of the highway has been inaugurated by Prime Minister on May 2018. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report later revised the expected closure date to 30-APR-21. Pakistani news outlet reports that M-3 section from Lahore to Abdul Hakeem was completed and delivered on March 31, 2019

title: China Export-Import Bank commits Government Concessional Loan of CNY1.2 billion to Pakistan for Lahore Orange Line Metro Train project (linked to project #53820 and #37280)
description:
The Government Pakistan first announced its interest in pursuing a project to develop a city-wide train system in the eastern city of Lahore on April 27, 2011. Lahore, the capital of Punjab province, is Pakistan’s most populous and prosperous province. It is home to more than 5 million people. Pakistani officials expected the new transport system, the first of its kind in the country, to substantially decrease road traffic. Then, on April 20, 2015, a commercial contract for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project: was signed between Punjab Mass Transit Authority (PMA) and CR-NORINCO [a joint venture of China State Railway Group Co. Ltd. (CR) and China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO)]. 

Shortly thereafter, on December 21, 2015, the China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed three separate loan agreements for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project: a $203.25 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, a $1,235,480,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement, and an RMB 1,200,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) loan agreement. The BCL (Project ID#53820 and loan ID#BC-OLL-2015) has a 5.2% interest rate and a 20 year maturity. The PBC (Project ID#37280 and loan ID#PBC-OLL15-34377) has a 20 year maturity and an unknown interest rate. The GCL (Project ID#54420 and loan ID#GCL-OLL15-20559) has a 2% interest rate and a 20 year maturity. According to the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division, $672.7 million of this “mixed credit” from China Eximbank had been disbursed as of June 30, 2017.  

The Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project involved the construction of a 27km two-lane metro bus corridor runs through the heart of Lahore along Multan Road, McLeod Road, and GT Road. Upon completion, the Orange Metro Line was expected to have capacity for 30,000 passenger per hour and  serve 250,000 passengers per day. CR-NORINCO — a joint venture of China State Railway Group Co. Ltd. (CR) and China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO) — was the entity responsible for project implementation. The project was initially expected to begin by the end of 2014, last for 27 months, and conclude in 2018. However, it encountered various delays.   

The Lahore Development Authority began marking sites for demolition in August 2015, including government buildings, royal tombs, mosques, schools, and residences. Civil works were then initiated by CN-NORINCO on October 25, 2015.  Popular protests  prompted the Lahore high court to suspend work surrounding heritage sites in January 2016 while the court deliberated the issue. Then, in August 2016, the Lahore high court ruled that the government could not evict people or harm the heritage sites. The Punjab provincial government challenged the ruling, and in April 2017, the Supreme Court reversed its decision, allowing construction to continue under 31 conditions to limit the disruption and damage of the project.  This project was ultimately completed on December 10, 2019. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 巴基斯坦拉合尔轨道交通“橙线”项目.

title: [CPEC]China provides Business Concessional Loan of US164.4 million for the Phase-II repair project of KKH Highway (Thakot-Havelian section) in Pakistan (Linked to projects #52525 and #54424)
description: On February 19, 2014, China Road and Bridge Corporation, a subsidiary of China Communications Corporation, and the Pakistan Ministry of Communications signed a memorandum of understanding on the Phase-II Reconstruction and Expansion of the Karakoram Highway (Raikot-Islamabad). After that, China Road and Bridge Company submitted the engineering feasibility study report and preliminary design of the project to the Highway Bureau. Due to the large amount of project and the high total cost of the 487-kilometer Raikot-Islamabad project, China and Pakistan have decided to divide the project into three sections. The first section is Thakot-Havelian section, the second section is the Havelian to Islamabad section, and the third section is the Thakot-Raikot section. In 2016, the Pakistan-China Joint Cooperation Committee approved the repair for the section of the Thakot-Havelian of the eastern route with length of 136 kilometers. As part of CPEC, this project being developed by the Pakistani government will be financed by concessionary loans, with composite interest rates of 1.6%. The concessional loans are subsidized by the government of China, and are to be dispersed by the Exim Bank of China and the China Development Bank. China Communication Construction Co. Ltd. is the project contractor, with the executive agency being Pakistan National Highway Authority. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report 2015-16 records three loans provided by China to Pakistan for this KKH project. The first part is noted as GCL (Government Concessional Loan) with an amount of CNY 1,200.00 million (equivalent to 180.64 million USD). The second part is noted as BCL with an amount of 164.40 million USD. The last part is noted as PBC with an amount of 966.19 million USD. It is unclear what the latter two labels stand for or whether they are provided by the Chinese government. The three parts add up to USD1311 million, which is fairly close to the CPEC-reported amount of USD1366 million. This project captures the BCL component; for the other two fundings, see projects #52525 and #54424. Below are other sources that corroborate the financial details above: A Pakistani government project status report in May from 2017-18 records that China has committed only CNY1.2 billion on the project, which is significantly lower than the CPEC project total amount. During January 2017, it was reported that Pakistan's Under Communication Division contributed 600 million Pakistani rupee towards the project. According to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2016-2017, the revised budget states that 20,500 million Pakistani rupees are likely to be disbursed in 2015-2016. In the Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017-2018, the Pakistan revised budget estimate predicts China to lend 11,137.010 million Pakistani rupees, or 82.96 million USD, to the project in 2016-2017. The budget estimate for 2017-2018 estimates China to lend 20,750 million Pakistani rupees, or 154.57 million USD, in that year. The 2016 Government of Pakistan Bond Prospectus lists the project cost as 1366 million USD, equal to the CPEC listed amount. The project is expected to be completed in 2018. STAFF_NOTE: The third proposed section of the Phase-II project from Thakot to Raikot is captured under project #53713. The project is still in the process of signing the Letter of Intent, and has not been confirmed. The second proposed section from Havelian to Islamabad is captured under project #52719.

title: China Eximbank provides loan to Uzbekistan for modernization of Cascade Tashkent Hydroelectric Power Plant (HPP-9)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the modernization of Cascade Tashkent Hydropower Plant (HPP-9) in Yunusabad region, Tashkent district. The total cost of the project is26,700,000, but the amount loaned by the Eximbank is unknown, so transaction amount has been left blank. Modernization of the hydropower plant will be carried out by the Power China company. The project will increase the plant's power to 16.6 MW and is expected to be implemented from 2017-2021.

title: China Eximbank provides loan for modernization of UE 'Cascade of Kadirin Hydroelectric Power Plant' (HPP-3)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for modernization of UE 'Cascade of Kadirin Hydroelectric Power Plant' (HPP-3) in Kibray district, Tashkent region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The total cost of the project is 27,600,000 USD, but the amount of the Eximbank loan is unknown. According to a UNECE report, the project is cofinanced by the IDB. The cascade consists of four HPPs. The project will increase the plant's power from 11.3 MW to 15.34 MW, and is expected to be implemented from 2017-2019. Project status is also unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Year is marked uncertain because some sources report the dates of the project as 2015-2017.

title: China Eximbank provides loan to Uzbekistan for modernization of Cascade Nijne-Bozsuv Hydroelectric Power Plant (HPP-14)
description: In 2017, China's Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the modernization of Cascade Nijne-Bozsuv Hydroelectric Power Plant (HPP-14) in Zangiata district, Tashkent region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The total project cost is 31,600,000 USD, but the contribution of the Eximbank is unknown. The cascade consists of five HPPs. The project will increase the plant's power to by 2.8 MW to 16 MW and is expected to be implemented from 2017-2019. According to a MarketWatch article, implementation has begun. Loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Cascade also referred to as Lower Bozsu, and can be spelled Nije-Buzsuz or Nizhne-Bozsu.

description: In 2017, China's Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the construction of Kamolot hydropower station on Chirchik-Bozsuv tract in Chirchik city, Tashkent region. title: China Eximbank provides loan for construction of cascade of Zarchob hydroelectric power stations on Tupalang river (linked to #54385)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the construction of a cascade of Zarchob hydroelectric power stations on Tupalang river in Sariasiya district, Surkhandarya region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The project cost is80,390,000, but the amount provided by the Eximbank is unknown. The stations will have a capacity of 69 MW, and the dates of implementation are 2017-2020. According to MarketWatch, construction began in June-August 2017. Loan details are unknown. This project is linked to ID #54385, the umbrella project for a58.5 million Eximbank loan for four hydropower plants.

implementing_agencies: Tianjin Model Vocational Training Institute, Academic, Training and Research
title: Chinese college sponsors vocational tranining institute Luban Workshop in Pakistan
description: During May 2017, an MoU was signed between Pakistan's Technical Education and Vocational Training Authority (TEVA) and the Tianjin Model Vocational Training College (TMVTC) in Tianjing China to construct a Luban workshop in Pakistan to help train skilled talents in honing there craft for professional quality. For the first half of 2018 the Luban workshop will provide Advanced Chinese Language and Automation Production Line, while during the second half of 2018 they will provide two more courses with one most likely being media arts. After the Luban workshop is constructed, Chinese master trainers will remain in Pakistan to supervise, in exchange for Pakistani master trainers being sent to China for training. The Luban workshop in Lahore, Pakistan, was unveiled in July 2018 according to a September 2018 Global Times news article. In March 2019, the Chinese implementing agency, Tianjin Modern Vocational Training Institute, published a press release that records, on January 16, 2019, the Luban Workshop in Pakistan was opened for operation. The first batch of 25 Pakistani students entered the Luban Workshop and began a six-month course. STAFF_NOTE: The intent has been coded as Mixed because there is Representational and Development intent, and the flow class was correspondingly coded as OOF-like.
sources: https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjhyJPwqIrhAhWHjVkKHb5hCJ8QFjAAegQIABAB&url=https%3A%2F%2Ftribune.com.pk%2Fstory%2F1593495%2F1-chinese-luban-workshop-start-classes-april%2F&usg=AOvVaw1EOkO0KnsO9v5FVHP7mFxd, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1119517.shtml?from=timeline, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.xdxy.com.cn/info/1036/6393.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjJwNv-gY3hAhWCCDQIHYzzBZgQFjAAegQIAhAB&url=https%3A%2F%2Ftribune.com.pk%2Fstory%2F1593495%2F1-chinese-luban-workshop-start-classes-april%2F&usg=AOvVaw1EOkO0KnsO9v5FVHP7mFxd, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 17th SAARC Summit
description: The Maldives Budget in Statistics 2013 document lists 'Aid given to the 17th SAARC Summit' as a grant from China, although it provides no transaction amount. This summit was held in 2011, so that year has been coded as the commitment year. No other available Budget in Statistics documents include information on the 17th SAARC Summit, and there are no Budget in Statistics documents available for 2010-2012. It is unclear what specific kind of aid China provided. According to a 2011 Reuters article, the post-summit giveaway bag included porcelain pens and diaries from the Chinese Foreign Affairs Ministry detailing “Five Years of China-SAARC Cooperation.” Additionally, a box for a new 40-inch TV in the media center was labeled 'China Aid'. According to a 2015 Nepal Republic Media article, China distributed bags with the slogan 'China-SAARC friendship' at the 2011 SAARC Summit in the Maldives. The intent has been coded as Mixed, because based on media sources it appears the aid likely had at least some representational intent.

title: Bank of China loans 120 million USD to expansion of Shalkiya zinc and lead mine
description: In December 2017, the Bank of China signed a loan syndicate agreement with EBRD to loan up to 120 million USD to JSC ShalkiyaZinc Ltd, a Kazakh mining company based in the Kyzylorda region, for a zinc and lead mine. This loan is part of an EBRD syndicated loan of 295 million USD that was offered in June 2017. The status and details of the loan are unknown. The NWF Samruk-Kazyna JSC signed an agreement with the EBRD at the The Trade Envoy of Great Britain for Kazakhstan to guarantee the loan.

title: China Eximbank provides loan for construction of Kamchik small hydropower station on Akhangaran river (linked to #54385)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the construction of Kamchik small hydropower station on Akhangaran river in Pap district, Namangan region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The project cost is27,200,000, but the amount of the Eximbank loan is unknown. The station will have a capacity of 18 MW and the dates of implementation are 2018-2021. According to MarketWatch, construction began in June-August 2017. This project is linked to project ID #54385, the umbrella project for an Eximbank loan for four hydropower plants.

funding_agencies: Bank of China (BOC), State-owned Company; China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
title: Line A and B of Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, Kazakhstan section (linked to #39997, #40833, #39955)
description: The Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, otherwise known as the China - Central Asia Gas Pipeline, a 1,873-km gas pipeline that connect Turkmenistan to China via Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan currently consists of 4 lines (A/B/C/D), with A,B,C parallel to each other. The pipeline starts at Gedaim on the border of Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, runs through central Uzbekistan and southern Kazakhstan, and ends at Horgos in China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. The line A (#40833) of this pipeline became operational in 2009 while the other two lines (B (#40834) and C (#39997)) started their operation in 2010 and 2014 respectively. Line A and B will be connected to the Second West-East Gas Pipeline, while Line C will be connected to the Third West-East Gas Pipeline. Line D (#39955) runs through Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan to Wuqia County in China, where it will be connected to the Fifth West-East Gas Pipeline. Line A, B, and C are providing 55 billion cubic meters of gas to China per annum, while Line D is still under construction. There are segments of each line constructed within Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, and Kyrgyzstan. Kazakhstan-China pipeline construction started in July 9 2008. This project records the financing of the Kazakhstan segment of Lines A and B. Project 39997 records the financing of the Kazakhstan segment of Line C. Line A and B starts on right bank of the Amu Darya River, near Turkmenistan/Uzbekistan border, and passes through the central region of Uzbekistan and southern region of Kazakhstan. Line A became operational in December 2009 (with a throughput capacity of 10 bcm per year), and Line B became operational in October 2010 (with a throughput capacity of 30 bcm per year). Line A and B's capacity has since been increased to 30 billion cubic meters of gas per year. (NOTE: In the 2018 base prospectus, the operational date of Line B was reported to be December 2012). JSC KazTransGas formed a joint venture with CNPC (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) called Asia Gas Pipeline LLP (AGP) to construct and operate the Kazakhstan-China Gas Pipeline. JSC KazTransGas and CNPC each holds 50% of AGP. In October 2008, AGP entered into a U.S.$7.5 billion syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank and Bank of China for the purposes of financing the development, construction and operation of lines A and B of the 'Kazakhstan-China' pipeline (NOTE: In the 2018 base prospectus, Line A and Line B were also referred to as the 'first and second phases of the construction of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline'). The loan bears interest at a rate of three-month LIBOR increased by 2.15 per cent. per annum during the guarantee period and three-month LIBOR increased by 2.9 per cent. per annum thereafter. The loan must be repaid in several installments from March 2013 until October 2023. The amounts due under this loan are secured by account charges, a pledge over deposit certificate agreement, an insurance assignment and are guaranteed by CNPC. As at 30 June 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under this loan was U.S.$4.5 million. According to these information, interest rate is recorded as 3M LIBOR in October 2008 (4.059%) + 2.15%; grace period = 4.5 years; repayment period = 10.5 years, maturity period = 15 years.
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://center.cnpc.com.cn/bk/system/2017/12/07/001671340.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://kase.kz/files/emitters/KZTG/kztgf9e1_2017.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China to build a small hydroelectric station on Sardoba reservoir
description: On May 17, 2017, President of Uzbekistan Shavkat Mirziyoyev declared that China had signed agreement for the construction of a new 15 MW hydroelectric power plant on the Sardoba Reservoir, Uzbekistan. The agreement was signed during Mirziyoyev's visit to China in 2017. The most up-to-date official source on the hydroelectric station on Sardoba reservoir is released on Feb 19, 2019, stating that the total costs of three projects ('modernization of Syrdarya thermal power station' and 'Farkhad hydroelectric station,''construction of a small hydroelectric station on Sardoba reservoir') would be 275 million USD, but the cost for this hydropower plant is unknown. Construction has begun on the projects.
sources: http://tashkenttimes.uz/economy/940-shavkat-mirziyoyev-inspects-sardoba-reservoir-construction-progress, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.uzdaily.uz/en/post/39411, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://uzbekistan.lv/en/new-company-in-hydro-energy-sphere-to-be-established-in-uzbekistan/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://mfa.uz/en/press/news/2019/02/17820/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.uzbekembassy.in/information-digest-of-press-of-uzbekistan-97-may-18-2017/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://kun.uz/en/news/2019/02/20/mirziyoyev-criticizes-officials-for-lack-of-industrial-facilities-in-rural-areas, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://web.archive.org/web/20180710093747/http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/zxxx_662805/t1464000.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

implementing_agencies: Bangladesh China Institute of Technology (BCIT), Academic, Training and Research; Lanzhou University, Academic, Training and Research
title: China provides technical assistance to construction of technical institute in Bangladesh
description: In 2017, China announced plans to assist with the construction of a technical institute in Bangladesh. China sent advisers to provide technical support in order to establish the institute, but it is unclear which Chinese entity sent them. The technical institute, with special focus on power engineering courses, will be set up under the supervision of Bangladesh China Institute of Technology (BCIT) and Lanzhou Jiaotong University of China. Under the course, students will study first two years in Dhaka at Stamford University and last two years at Lanzhou Jiaotong University in China for getting first hand practical training with modern lab facilities. The power engineering course following Chinese curriculum started in 2018 January.
sources: https://www.jagonews24.com/en/education/news/33934, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ENEPOW0020171121edbu00008&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.daily-sun.com/printversion/details/267258/Chinese-university-to-launch-Power-Engineering-course-in-Bangladesh, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency; Gazprom, Private Sector
title: China Development Bank financing for construction of an oil refinery complex in Jizzakh region
description: In 2017, China Development Bank provided debt financing for the construction of an oil refinery complex in Zafarabad district, Jizzakh region, Uzbekistan, as reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan. The project is cofinanced by Gazprombank of Russia and BELVOR Holdings Ltd of Cyprus. The total cost of the project is2.2 billion, but the amount financed by China Development Bank is unknown. Construction began in April 2017, and the dates of implementation are 2017-2020.Once completed, the refinery will produce 3.7 million tpy of motor fuel conforming to Euro 5-quality specifications, as well as 700,000 tpy of aviation fuel and 300,000 tpy of other finished products. The refinery will receive raw materials via pipeline from Russia and Kazakhstan.The contractors for the project are Enter Engineering Pte. Ltd. of Russia, Amec Foster Wheeler PLC of the UK, and Hyundai Engineering Co. Ltd. of South Korea. Once complete, the plant will be operated by the recently formed Jizzakh Petroleum JV LLC.
sources: https://www.ogj.com/articles/2017/09/uzbekistan-lets-contract-for-refinery-in-jizzakh-region.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://invest.gov.uz/en/invest-projects-taxonomy/realizuemye-investitsionnye-proekty/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.ogj.com/articles/2017/05/uzbekistan-breaks-ground-on-new-refinery.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Chinese Government, Government Agency
title: China sends second round of relief aid for Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh (linked to project #54502)
description: On September 28, 2017, a second Chinese cargo plane arrived with humanitarian aid for displaced Rohingya refugees in the Chittagong province of Bangladesh. The aid consisted of some 2,000 tents and 3,000 blankets, but the financial value of the aid is unknown. Previously on September 27, the first batch of humanitarian aid was delivered (see project #54502). It is unknown from which body of the Chinese government this aid originated from. On October 4, Bangladeshi soldiers started to build Chinese relief tents to accommodate the Rohingyas people crossing into the country from Myanmar.
sources: https://www.thedailystar.net/world/rohingya-crisis/china-india-uk-send-750-tonnes-refugee-aid-relief-materials-myanmar-violence-1468978, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PEODEN0020170929ed9t00013&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.xinhuanet.com//english/2017-10/05/c_136658982.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.people.cn/n3/2017/0929/c90000-9275183.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.xinhuanet.com//english/2017-09/28/c_136646271.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://fts.unocha.org/flows/165008?destination=donors/2976/flows/2017%3Ff%255B0%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2521%26f%255B1%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522704%253ABANGLADESH%2520-%2520Rohingya%2520Refugee%2520Crisis%2520%2528from%25202017%2529%2522, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: China sends first round of relief aid for Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh
description: On September 27th, 2018, a Chinese cargo plane carrying 57 tons of humanitarian aid arrived in Chittagong, Bangladesh. The aid is meant to assist the Rohingya refugees displaced from Myanmar. It is unknown which part of the Chinese government provided the aid. The value of the aid is unknown. The next day, China sent a second cargo plane with more aid (project #54501) to help Bangladesh and the refugees.

title: [BRI] Chinese EXIM Bank loans 12.27 billion taka to connect 2,600 union buildings
description:
In 2017, Bangladesh's Minister of Information, Communications, and Technology stated that a loan agreement will be agreed upon with the China EXIM Bank. The Minister said that the project would be implemented by 2018 with an estimated cost of Taka 1,999.49 crore (ten million), while Taka 1,227 crore will come from China as assistance. Once completed, about 100,000 rural educational institutions will be connected by fiber optic cables. The project is still ongoing as of 2019.

This project is part of the initiative ‘one-belt, one-road’ that aims at expanding links between Asia, Africa and Europe.
STAFF_NOTE: Since no loan details are known, this project is marked as vague official finance.

title: Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline (Kenkiyak-Kumkol) (linked to #39605 and #54523)
description: JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed joint venture Limited Liability Partnership Kazakhstan-China Pipeline (KCP) on July 6, 2004, to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, comprising two of three pipeline systems forming the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstan oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owns 50% of the joint venture. The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network comprises three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are currently operational. The Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured in #39605. As at 31 December 2017, the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline had a total length of 962 km of pipe with diameters between 0.5 m and 1.8 m. In the year ended 31 December 2017, the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline transported 12.3 million tonnes of crude oil. The Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline was completed in October 2009 with a total of 794 km of pipe with diameter of 813mm, and as at 31 December 2017, the length of the pipeline was 794.0 km and had a throughput capacity of 9.2 million tonnes of crude oil per year. In the year ended 31 December 2017, the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline transported 5.2 million tonnes of crude oil. Pursuant to an agreement between the Company and CNODC, the capacity of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline increased to 20 million tonnes of crude oil in 2015, which is expected to enable the Company to accommodate the expected increased production at the Tengiz Field, as well as production at the Kashagan Field when commercial production achieves its expected potential. Ten companies supply oil to the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. This project records the financing to the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. On 12 August 2008, KCP entered into a U.S.$1.18 billion credit facility with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited and ING Bank N.V. with a term of ten years, subject to extension for up to five additional years. This credit facility was entered into for the purpose of financing construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. KCP had the right to draw down the loan in four tranches, three of which were drawn down during 2008 in an aggregate principal amount of U.S.$1.0 billion. The availability period for this credit facility expired at the end of 2011. Amounts borrowed under the facility accrued interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 2% per annum until February 2013 and six-month LIBOR plus 4% per annum thereafter and are guaranteed by CNPC. As at 31 December 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this facility was U.S.$403.9 million (including the capitalised interest) (KZT 134.3 billion). Based on the information above, the interest rate is recorded as 6 Month Libor in August 2008 (3.108%) + 2%, which is 5.108%. Maturity period is 10 years and grace period is 0. STAFF_NOTE: As the loan financiers include a non-Chinese financier - ING Bank N.V., and the breakdown of loan amounts between the 2 financiers are not known, a transaction amount has not been recorded for this project. However, IJ Global reported that there are 6 financiers - ING Bank, ICBC, CDB, China Exim Bank, Bank of China, Bank of Communications, and that each one contributed 196.67 Million USD. CRS sector 32262 (oil and gas).
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/projects/project1?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/company/about?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: Kazakhstan-China Pipeline refinanced notes issued in 2005 through facility agreement with ICBC (linked to #40833)
description: JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed joint venture Limited Liability Partnership Kazakhstan-China Pipeline (KCP) on July 6, 2004, to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, comprising two of three pipeline systems forming the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstan oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owns 50% of the joint venture. The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network comprises three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are currently operational. In August 2013, KCP entered into a U.S.$300.0 million facility agreement with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited and ICBC Almaty for the purpose of refinancing its notes issued in 2005. Loans drawn down under this facility bear interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 3.75% per annum. As at 31 December 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was U.S.$180.0 million (KZT 59.8 billion). Based on this information, interest rate is recorded as 6M LIBOR in August 2013 (0.395%) + 3.75% = 4.145%

funding_agencies: Bank of China (BOC), State-owned Company; China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency; China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), State-owned Company
title: Line C of Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, Uzbekistan section (linked to #40833)
description:
Uzbekneftegaz National Holding Company and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) created a joint venture named Asia Trans Gas in April 2008 for construction of the Uzbekistan section of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline (also known as Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline) Line C. Line C is 1830 km in length, 529km of which is within Uzbekistan. With a designed capacity of 25 billion cubic meters per annum, Line C’s pipe diameter is 1,219mm, 152mm larger than Line A/B. Line C starts at Turkmenistan-Uzbekistan border and ends at Horgos, in the Xinjiang region of China. According to CNPC, construction of Line C was started in September 2012, and the overall welding work of the pipeline was completed at the end of 2013. Line C became operational in May 2014. The total project cost of Line C Uzbekistan segment was 2.2 billion USD. 

China Development Bank provided a loan of 1.2 billion USD to Asia Trans Gas to this project. The exact commitment year is unknown, and the year which CNPC and Uzbekneftegaz signed an agreement on construction and operation of Line C of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline (September 21, 2011), is taken as the commitment year.  
 
STAFF_NOTES: No loan details were found regarding this project.
sources: http://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/FlowofnaturalgasfromCentralAsia/FlowofnaturalgasfromCentralAsia2.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.pfie.com/Journals/2014/02/12/o/l/l/PFILeagueTables2013.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/tupxw/200912/20091206674970.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.agp.com.kz/?p=1605, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China Provides Technical Cooperation Program to Jumhoriate Hospital
description: On January 22, the Chinese and Afghan government signed an agreement to provide a Technical Cooperation Program to the Jumhoriate Hospital that will last 2 years and will focus on the hospital's maintenance and will feature on-site technical guidance and personnel training for the maintenance of the hospital's main equipment and also for supplying necessary spare parts for the equipment. STAFF_NOTE: Alternatively known as Jamhuriate hospital. Can't find an article related to the program's completion but it likely occurred. China also funded the renovation of the Jumhoriate hospital in 2002 (see project ID #34502).

title: China Exim Bank loans 199.5 Million USD to Development Bank of Kazakhstan for deeper oil refining complex
description: On 15 October 2012, DBK entered into a U.S.$199.5 million preferential buyer credit loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China to finance the construction of a deep oil refining complex in Atyrau, which was amended on 30 October 2014. This loan matures on 15 October 2025 and bears interest at a rate of 3% per annum. As at 30 June 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under this preferential buyer credit loan agreement was U.S.$179.5 million.

title: China Eximbank loans $77 million for Kungrad Soda Ash Plant (linked to #39943)
description: In September 2012, China's Export Import Bank issued a loan of77 million for the expansion of the Kungrad Soda Ash Plant in the Karakalpakstan region of Uzbekistan. The project expanded the plant's capacity from 100,000 to 200,000 tons per year. The loan has a maturity of 20 years, but the interest rate and grace period are unknown. The total project cost is 110 million, and financing was also provided by the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan and state joint stock company Uzkimyosanoat. China's CITIC Co, Ltd. designed and supplied equipment for the project. The project took two years and was completed in 2016. This project is linked to #39943, an ICBC loan in 2003 for the construction of the plant.

title: China Eximbank loan for the construction of the 266 km Merke-Burylbaytal road (BRI)
description:
On May 15, 2017, KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) and China Eximbank signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 262 km Merke-Burylbaytal road. The total cost of this project is $363 million and China Eximbank has agreed to cover 85% of the cost, so we estimate that the face value of the loan is $308.55 million.  This loan carries the following terms: a 2% interest rate and a 20 year year maturity. The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan. The contractor responsible for project implementation is Xinxing Construction Group. Reconstruction of the road started May 16, 2019. 

The reconstruction of the Merke-Burylbaytal road, 262 km long, is divided into 4 sections, of which the road section from Merke to Shu, 86 km long, will be listed under the first technical category with 4-lane traffic. The remaining 3 sections from the town of Shu to the village of Burybaytal with a length of 176 km will be listed under the technical category II with 2 lanes. The road will pass through the settlements of Tatti, Shu, Birlik. The reconstruction project involves the construction of 6 bridges, 3 overpasses over the railroad, 11 illuminated traffic intersections, 276 culverts, recreation areas, and auto pavilions. The project is expected to be completed in June 2022. 

According to an 2018 financial report from KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company, it signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project  (Project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID# 54991). PBC loans from China Eximbank cover pay 85% of the total cost of a project, and we know from the total cost for each of these 4 projects (from a China MOFCOM source). Therefore, we can estimate the value of each PBC loan commitment by taking 85% of the total project cost. These calculations result in PBC loan value estimations of $434.35 million for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54990), $796 million for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project  (Project ID#55016),  $308.55 million for the the Merke-Burylbaital Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54989), and $147.05 million (85% of $173 million US dollars) for Astana Bypass Road (Project ID# 54991). The sum of these 4 estimate PBC loan values is $1,685,950,000,which is very close to $1,667,577,000 provided by KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company its in 2018 financial report. All four of these loans carry a 2% interest rate and a 20 year year maturity, according to KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company.

262 km road from Merke to Burylbaytal. The first 86km section runs from Merke to Shu. The remaining 3 road sections run from the town of Shu to the village of Burybaytal with a length of 176 km. The road will pass through the settlements of Tatti, Shu, Birlik.

STAFF_NOTE: The official Chinese project name for the road is 梅尔克-布鲁拜塔尔公路改造. The Russian project title is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканско-го значения «Мерке –Бурылбайтал» км 7-273. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of this project is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路改造.
sources: http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/v-zhambylskoj-oblasti-nachalas-realizatsiya-proekta-rekonstruktsii-a-d-merke-burylbajtal-km-7-273, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://primeminister.kz/en/news/all/gosprogramma-nurli-zhol-avtomobilnie-dorogi-logistika-zhkh-16616, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22443-108629.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.gtai.de/GTAI/Navigation/DE/Trade/Maerkte/suche,t=china-weitet-engagement-in-kasachstan-aus,did=1806084.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://kw.china-embassy.org/eng/xwdt/t1463732.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/kompaniya-kazavtozhol-podpisala-dvustoronnee-soglashenie-v-ramkakh-foruma-odin-poyas-odin-put, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://roads.miid.gov.kz/kk/news/merki-burylbaytal-7-273-km-avtozholyn-kayta-zhanartu-zhumystary-bastaldy, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China Eximbank loan for Kalbatau-Maykapshagai (415 km) road (BRI)
description:
On May 15, 2017, KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) and China Eximbank signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project.  The total cost of this project is $511 million and China Eximbank has agreed to cover 85% of the cost, so we estimate that the face value of the loan is $434.35 million. This PBC carries the following terms: a 2% interest rate and a 20 year year maturity. The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan. The contractor responsible for project implementation is Xinxing Construction Group.  According to Xinxing Construction group, construction began in April 2019. Project completion is expected in June 2022. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of this project is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路改造. 

According to an 2018 financial report from KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company, it signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project  (Project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID# 54991). PBC loans from China Eximbank cover pay 85% of the total cost of a project, and we know from the total cost for each of these 4 projects (from a China MOFCOM source). Therefore, we can estimate the value of each PBC loan commitment by taking 85% of the total project cost. These calculations result in PBC loan value estimations of $434.35 million for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54990), $796 million for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project  (Project ID#55016),  $308.55 million for the the Merke-Burylbaital Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54989), and $147.05 million (85% of $173 million US dollars) for Astana Bypass Road (Project ID# 54991). The sum of these 4 estimate PBC loan values is $1,685,950,000,which is very close to $1,667,577,000 provided by KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company its in 2018 financial report. All four of these loans carry a 2% interest rate and a 20 year year maturity, according to KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company.

This is a 415 km road that runs from Kalbatau to Maykapshagai.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is "卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路".
sources: https://primeminister.kz/en/news/all/gosprogramma-nurli-zhol-avtomobilnie-dorogi-logistika-zhkh-16616, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/predsedatel-ao-nk-azavtozhol-proveril-khod-rabot-ob-ektov-rekonstruktsii-v-vostochno-kazakhstanskoj-oblasti, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.xxg.com.cn/s/2751-6844-30683.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.xxg.com.cn/s/1312-4622-24.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/kompaniya-kazavtozhol-podpisala-dvustoronnee-soglashenie-v-ramkakh-foruma-odin-poyas-odin-put, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China Eximbank loan for southwest bypass road of Astana (33 km) (BRI)
description:
On May 15, 2017, KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) and China Eximbank signed a $147.05 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 33 km Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project.  This project is sometimes also called the 33 km Astana Ring Road Project (or Southwest Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project or the XH33 Project or «Астана қаласының айналма жолы»).  The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan. It has a maturity of 20 years and an interest rate of 2%. The total cost of the project is $173 million and China Eximbank agreed to cover 85% of the total project cost. Xinxing Construction Group is the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction started in December 2017 and the road was expected to be fully operational by 2019. 

According to an 2018 financial report from KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company, it signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project  (Project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID# 54991). PBC loans from China Eximbank cover pay 85% of the total cost of a project, and we know from the total cost for each of these 4 projects (from a China MOFCOM source). Therefore, we can estimate the value of each PBC loan commitment by taking 85% of the total project cost. These calculations result in PBC loan value estimations of $434.35 million for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54990), $796 million for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project  (Project ID#55016),  $308.55 million for the the Merke-Burylbaital Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54989), and $147.05 million (85% of $173 million US dollars) for Astana Bypass Road (Project ID# 54991). The sum of these 4 estimate PBC loan values is $1,685,950,000, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 provided by KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company its in 2018 financial report. All four of these loans carry a 2% interest rate and a 20 year year maturity, according to KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company.

This project is supporting the construction of a 33 km southwest section of the ring road (bypass road) around the city of Astana -- from the road to the airport to the M36 highway. Further locational details are provided at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/astana-southwest-bypass-road-construction/38a208f4-305f-4a0c-891b-4ab678753cdd/ and http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/trans/publications/Report_-_Kazakhstan_as_a_transport_logistics_centre_Europe-Asia.pdf.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is "努尔苏丹市西南环城公路".
sources: http://kz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/t/201807/20180702767861.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.government.kz/en/novosti/1015138-development-of-the-astana-agglomeration-discussed-in-the-government-of-the-republic-of-kazakhstan.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.sasac.gov.cn/n2588025/n2641611/n4518442/c11103815/content.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://primeminister.kz/en/news/all/gosprogramma-nurli-zhol-avtomobilnie-dorogi-logistika-zhkh-16616, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China Eximbank loan for the reconstruction of the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) segment of the Almaty-Oskemen road project
description:
In May 2016, China CITIC Corporation signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol for reconstructing the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) segment of the Almaty-Oskemen road project (1003 km). The road also passes through Kalbatau. In November 2016, China Eximbank provided a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan for the the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project. The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan. The loan legally entered into force in June 2017. It has a maturity of 20 years and an interest rate of 2%. The total cost of the project is $936 million and China Eximbank agreed to cover 85% of the total project cost. 

On June 7, 2017, the EPC contractor (CITIC Construction) received an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work. Construction then began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete. 

According to an 2018 financial report from KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company, it signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project  (Project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID# 54991). PBC loans from China Eximbank cover pay 85% of the total cost of a project, and we know from the total cost for each of these 4 projects (from a China MOFCOM source). Therefore, we can estimate the value of each PBC loan commitment by taking 85% of the total project cost. These calculations result in PBC loan value estimations of $434.35 million for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54990), $796 million for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project  (Project ID#55016),  $308.55 million for the the Merke-Burylbaital Road Reconstruction Project (Project ID#54989), and $147.05 million (85% of $173 million US dollars) for Astana Bypass Road (Project ID# 54991). The sum of these 4 estimate PBC loan values is $1,685,950,000, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 provided by KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company its in 2018 financial report. All four of these loans carry a 2% interest rate and a 20 year year maturity, according to KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company.

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111/.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project.
sources: https://primeminister.kz/en/news/all/gosprogramma-nurli-zhol-avtomobilnie-dorogi-logistika-zhkh-16616, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.construction.citic/content/details_47_1844.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.gtai.de/GTAI/Navigation/DE/Trade/Maerkte/suche,t=china-weitet-engagement-in-kasachstan-aus,did=1806084.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: China provides 1 million USD in cash assistance to Afghanistan earthquake relief
description: In October 2015 in response to an earthquake, China provided 10 million Chinese yuan in emergency material aid to Afghanistan and announced that Vice Chairman Li Yuanchao would provide an additional 1 million USD in cash assistance. The material aid was delivered to Afghanistan in November 3, 2015. STAFF_NOTE: This project records the 1 million USD of cash assistance. The emergency material aid is recorded in #53817.
sources: https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/web/zyxw/t1311738.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Development Bank loan to United Chemical Company LLP
description: The 13th National Report On the implementation of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative in the Republic of Kazakhstan for 2017 reported that United Chemical Company LLP received a loan from the State Development Bank of China in the amount of 409 million US dollars (equivalent to 134.970 million tenge at the exchange rate on the date of receipt). This may be related to the agreement signed between China Development Bank and United Chemical Company LLP in June 2017 on the implementation of investment projects for the production of methanol and ammonia in the National Industrial Petrochemical Technopark Special Economic Zone (SEZ), in the Atyrau region, as well as the production of caustic soda in the Chemical Park Taraz SEZ, in the Zhambyl region. The signed project is being implemented as part of the development of Kazakhstan's first agrochemical cluster. No other loan information can be found.
sources: http://lenta.inform.kz/en/kazakhstan-china-business-council-starts-in-kazakhstan_a3034112, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://sk.kz/press-centre/media/19444/?lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://eiti.org/sites/default/files/documents/english_2017_eiti_report_kazakhstan.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: Bank of China refinances 2010 loan to Caspi Bitum LLP
description: In September 2010, Caspi Bitum LLP, a joint venture between KMG RM and CITIC, entered into a U.S.$232 million loan agreement with the Bank of China for the purpose of funding the proposed road bitumens production plant at the plastics plant in Aktau. On 17 June 2016, Caspi Bitum LLP entered into two additional loan agreements with the Bank of China in an aggregate principal amount of U.S.$208 million, for the purposes of refinancing the loan entered into in 2010. As of 2018, such funds have been drawn down and the 2010 loan has been fully repaid.
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

funding_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: China Communications Construction Co., Ltd. (CCCC), State-owned Company
title: [BRI] China EXIM Bank provides USD Denominated concessional loan worth for $405.8 million to Bangladesh for Multi Lane Road Tunnel under River Karnaphuli (linked to #52873 and #38342)
description: On October 14, 2016, the Chinese EXIM Bank signed a loan agreement with Bangladesh to fund the second railway bridge across the Karnaphuli River at Kalughat point. The loan package came in the form of a 405,800,000 USD loan (project #38342) and a separate 1,791,608,000 CNY loan (project #55046). Both loans have a 20 year repayment period and a 2% interest rate. This project is a part of the Belt and Road Initiative and one of a series of loans described in umbrella project #52873. June 2014, Bangladesh and China signed a memorandum of understanding on the construction of a tunnel under the Karnaphuli River. In June 2015, the road transport and bridges ministry of Bangladesh signed a US$705 million deal with China Communication Construction Company to implement the multi-lane tunnel to be constructed beneath the Karnaphuli River in Chittagong. This bridge will be located next to the existing Kalurghat railway bridge. The project will cost around 1.07 billion USD total, with the government of Bangladesh covering the remainder of the expenses. According to news reports from the Chinese state news agency Xinhua News, the construction started formally in Dec 5, 2017 after preliminary investigations, and was still in implementation as of Feb 2019. The project duration is expected to be 5 years. STAFF_NOTE: The grace period is unknown, however, this projects repayment period and interest period match the typical EXIM concessional loan terms, making a grace period of 5 years likely. The grace period is not included to avoid overstating the volume of Chinese giving. Even with a grace period of zero years, this project would have a grant element over 25%, so it was confidently coded as ODA-like.

title: China provides USD200,000 tsunami relief aid to Sri Lanka in cash
description: In response to the tsunami disaster on the Indian Ocean in December 2004, the Chinese government provides US$200,000 in cash for disaster relief to Sri Lanka.

title: China provides two rounds of assistance total worth of USD80000 for earthquake relief in Kyrgyz Republic
description: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs records that on 26/11/2015, Chinese government provided USD50,000 for the people affected by earthquake on 17 November 2015 in Kyrgyz Republic. Later on 15/12/2015, the Guangdong province of the People's Republic of China provided another USD30,000. The source records the project as commitment. The Chinese state media Xinhua News Agency also reports that, according to the Chinese diplomat in the local region of the earthquake in Kyrgyzstan, Song Liqun, the Chinese embassy had sent emergency materials such as quilts and pillows to the affected region.

description: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service records that on 04/04/2005, Chinese government made a total of 8 contributions to the World Health Organization to help provide health services in Maldives after the earthquake/tsunami on the Indian Ocean in December 2004. The contributions total USD671,450. They include: Assessment of the damage to the overall health system in the disaster-affected areas Support to MoH coordination Provision of supplies and equipment and replenishment of assets Technical support Advocacy and capacity building Disease surveillance Project management, evaluation and reporting Environmental Health monitoring and surveillance Restoration of Water and Sanitation Systems in the Disaster Affected Area

funding_agencies: Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, State-owned Company
title: Chinese NGO donates $10,000 USD to tsunami relief efforts in Sri Lanka (Linked to project #34817)
description: Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries (CPAFFC) has donated40,000 to the severely tsunami-hit countries and asked some friendly organizations of the disaster countries to convey its regards, said head of the organization Chen Haosu here Saturday. Out of the40,000 USD,10,000 USD was given to Sri Lanka. The rest of the money was presumably distributed among the other tsunami-affected countries including India, Indonesia, Thailand, and Maldives (linked to project #34817). STAFF_NOTES: China contributed 63 million USD for tsunami relief in total, most of the individual project are captured (see projects linked with resource #41811). STAFF_NOTE: As the exact financial breakdown among the recipient countries is unclear, the project has no transaction amount for now. The details should be added if information is found in the future.
