implementing_agencies: Shandong High Speed Qilu Construction Group Haiyang Corporation Ltd. (山东高速齐鲁建设集团海阳有限公司), State-owned Company
title: China builds a hospital and school in Baffa, Pakistan after 2005 earthquake (Linked to project #53903)
description: After the earthquake in Pakistan in 2005, China government soon pledged to help with the reconstruction efforts. According to the assessment of the disaster after the earthquake, the Chinese government promised to build a school and a hospital without compensation. After consultations between the relevant departments of the two countries, the project was finally confirmed in the town of Bava in Mansella. The formal agreement was signed on 24-11-2006. The project includes the construction of a 6,525-square-meter high school (GHSS Baffa) that cost Rs 487.5 million and a small hospital of 4,400 square meters (THQ Baffa) which cost cost Rs 412.5 million to impart education for 720 students. At the beginning of 2011, an advance team of 6 people from the Shandong Expressway Qilu Construction Group arrived in Baval and began the project preparation work. The construction officially started on July 2, 2011. From December 16 to 22, 2011, the mid-term quality inspection team organized by the Economic Cooperation Bureau of the Ministry of Commerce inspected and accepted the main structural project of the project. After strict and careful inspection by the leaders and experts, the project passed the quality acceptance. STAFF_NOTE: In 2015, China agreed to update the buildings by installing waste management and drainage systems, etc. Details of this project is captured under 53903.
sources: http://fp.brecorder.com/2015/12/201512221257985/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/Trainings/Website%20Year%20Book%202014--15.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.sdhsg.com/main/news/page.jsp?id=3259, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://ihl.cankaoxiaoxi.com/2012/1106/115275.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Norinco, State-owned Company; Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL), State-owned Company
title: Chinese EXIM Bank Concessionally Loans 1.75 billion USD for RPCL-NORINCO Intl. Power Ltd.'s Debt Portion of Patuakhali 1320 (2 x 600) MW Coal Fired Thermal Power Plant (linked to projects # # # # # #)
description:
In 2017, China Eximbank provide a loan worth approximately $1.75 billion to RPCL-NORINCO Intl. Power Ltd. (RNPL) for the construction of the Patuakhali 1320 (2 x 600) MW Coal Fired Thermal Power Plant. RNPL is a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) created by Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL) and NORINCO Intl. in 2017 to oversee the financing, design, and construction of this power plant. RPCL is a Bangladeshi state-owned electrification enterprise and NORINCO Intl. is a Chinese state-owned arms manufacturing company. The two state-owned enterprises registered their venture, RPCL-NORINCO Intl. Power Ltd. (RNPL) with the Government of Bangladesh’s Registrar of Joint Stock Companies and Firms on December 27, 2017. 

The total cost of the project is approximately $2.5 billion. It is reportedly being financed according to a 70:30 debt-to-equity ratio. RPCL and NORINCO each hold 50% equity shares in the project company. At the time of creation, RNPL had 200,000,000 BDT, with a maximum authorized capital of 400,000,000 BDT. The value of the Chinese equity funding is unclear. Since NORINCO held 50% of RNPL’s equity, the NORINCO funding may equal 100,000,000 BDT (approximately 1.2 million USD in December 2017). However, since the total project cost is 2.5 billion USD, and NORINCO owns half of the 30% equity share in the project company, NORINCO’s equity contribution could be as high at 15% of $2.5 billion, or $375 million USD. To avoid inaccurately representing the value of this investment, no transaction amount is recorded for the equity portion of this project for the time being (reported in Project ID #56357). 

China Eximbank is providing the debt financing for this project. Its loan to RNPL reportedly carries a 4% interest rate, 5 year grace period, and 20 year maturity. Project ID#56402 only captures the debt financing that came from the China Eximbank loan. The precise face value of the China Eximbank loan is unknown. However, RNPL has stated that the total project cost is $2.5 billion, and that 70% of the funding would come from the China Eximbank loan, which implies a  value of $1.75 billion. During the implementation of the 1320 (2 x 600) MW Patuakhali Coal-Fired Thermal Power Plant Project, RNPL will construct a coal jetty, coal import-handling facilities, coal storage, the power plant, transmission facilities, roads, and the town surrounding the plant. The project will process 12273 tons of coal per day and sell power to the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB). 

This power plant will operate on 915.74 acres of land. The plant will displace 350 families, so RPCL will set up a village with schools, shops, community centers, and mosques. On March 6, 2019, RNPL signed an EPC contract with NORINCO International Cooperation Ltd. and it issued a notice to proceed (NTP) to the EPC contractor on August 31, 2019. China Energy Engineering Group Tianjin Electric Power Construction Co.,Ltd. and Central Southern China Electric Power Design Institute of China Power Engineering Consulting Group Corporation are also involved in the design and implementation of the project. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of this project is 孟加拉博杜阿卡利1320MW燃煤电站项目建设 or Patuakhali 2台66万千瓦燃煤电站业主工程师咨询服务项目. The exact commitment date of the China Eximbank loan for this project is unknown. However, the RPCL Managing Director announced the loan terms in November 2017, the same month the two firms signed the joint venture agreement, making 2017 the likely year in which the loan agreement was finalized.

Tthere are three different power plants being constructed in the Patuakhali region of Bangladesh. Each one of these projects is funded partially via joint ventures between Chinese and Bangladeshi state-owned enterprises and partially via China Eximbank loans. Two of the coal-fired plants will contain two 660MW generators, with the third project involves two phases, both of which have two 660MW generators. The joint venture partners have clarified that these plants are near each other, but they are distinct plants supporting a region-wide electrification campaign.

These projects include: (1) Bangladesh’s Northwest Power Generation Company Ltd. and China National Machinery Import & Export Corporation, which established the Bangladesh-China Power Company Ltd. (BCPCL) joint venture in October 2014 to oversee the financing, design, and construction of Patuakhali 1320MW (2 x 660MW) Ultra Supercritical Coal Based Thermal Power Plant Project (Phase 2). The joint venture is captured in Project ID #56005. China Eximbank is funding phase one (units 1 and 2) of this project (see Project ID #52748). China Eximbank financing for phase two (units 3 and 4) is currently unspecified, with the most recent details record in Project ID #38245. 

(2) Bangladesh’s Ashuganj Power Station Company Ltd. (APSCL) and China’s China Energy Engineering Corporation Ltd. (CEEC) established a joint venture in July 2017 to oversee the financing, design, and construction of  Patuakhali 1320MW (2 x 660MW) Coal-Fired Power Plant (Ashuganj/ APSCL). The joint venture is captured in Project ID #56547. CEEC will solicit a loan from the China Eximbank for the debt portion of the project. China Eximbank financing for this project is currently not captured in a stand-alone Project ID#. 

(3) Bangladesh’s Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL) and China’s NORINCO, which established a joint venture in November 2017 to oversee the financing, design, and construction of 1320MW (2 x 660MW) MW Patuakhali Coal Fired Thermal Power Plant. The joint venture is captured in Project ID #56357. China Eximbank debt financing for the project is captured in Project ID#56402.
recipient_agencies: Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL), State-owned Company

title: ICBC Facility I to Reliance Communications (linked to #54352)
description:
On February 22, 2012, Reliance Communications entered into a $925.2 million term loan facility agreement (ICBC Facility I) with China Development Bank Corporation, Export-Import Bank of China and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited. The loan carried an interest rate of LIBOR plus a margin of 4.75%. The purpose of the loan was to help Reliance Communications repay its debts. As of December 31, 2014, $796 million of the principal amount was outstanding under this facility. In February 2019, Reliance Communications filed for bankruptcy as it was unable to sell assets to repay its debts. 

STAFF_NOTE: The interest rate was calculated by adding the 6-Month LIBOR rate at the time of agreement (0.757%) to the margin of 4.75%.
sources: https://www.ft.com/content/ef4567b4-0810-11e0-8527-00144feabdc0, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://links.sgx.com/FileOpen/Reliance%20Communications%20-%20Final%20OC.ashx?App=Prospectus&FileID=26422, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

funding_agencies: China Export-Import Bank, State-owned Company
implementing_agencies: China Energy Engineering Group, State-owned Company
title: PowerChina constructs Sirajganj 3x225MW Combined Cycle Power Plant in Bangladesh with China EXIM Financing
description:
On October 10, 2015, China Eximbank and Bank of China signed a $119.4 million syndicated loan agreement with North-West Power Generation Company Limited for Unit 2 of the 220MW Sirajganj Combined Cycle Power Plant Project (also known as the Sirajganj 2 Project). Northwest Power Generation Company Limited is a state owned power and electric company in Bangladesh. It is a 100% subsidiary of Bangladesh Power Development Board. The loan reportedly carries a 15 year maturity. It is insured by Sinosure and it received a sovereign guarantee from the Government of Bangladesh. 

The proceeds of the loan are to be used to finance part of the costs of goods and services under a turnkey EPC contract (signed on August 20, 2014) with China Machinery Import & Export Corporation (CMC) and Fujian Electric Power Survey & Design Institute (FEDI). $68.9 million in additional financing for the project followed in December 2015 when MIGA committed to a guarantee for the non-honoring of sovereign financial obligations against loans from Standard Chartered ($44 million) and Siemens Bank ($24.9 million). CMC is the consortium leader, and will provide overall project management while FEDI will provide technical expertise, including concept design and basic engineering. The turbines will be supplied by Siemens AG (Germany). The same EPC team (CMC, FEDI, Siemens) was responsible for the construction, commissioning and early operation of the first unit of electricity generators (“Sirajganj 1”). 

The Sirajganj 220MW Combined Cycle Power Plant is a major project under the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). It involves the installation of 3 units of electricity generators, each of 225MW capacity. It is an expansion of the existing 150MW power plant on the Jamunja river. The proceeds of the 2015 syndicated loan from Bank of China and the Export-Import Bank of China only supported the installation of the second unit of electricity generators (“Sirajganj 2”, which passed the final inspection tests in February 2018. The second unit of the power plant began commercial operations on February 5, 2018.  The project involved the construction, installation and operation of a 225 MW dual fuel CCPP (similar to Sirajganj 1) within the Sirajganj Power Complex, comprising a dual-fuel gas turbine, generator, steam turbine and a heat recovery steam generator (HRSG), water treatment and cooling system, as well as the construction of a 230 kV switchyard and an extension of the existing 230 kV switching station within the Sirajganj Power Complex. The project utilized the existing jetty for unloading heavy equipment, access roads and water treatment and cooling systems that were constructed for Sirajganj 1. 

Staff Note: This power plant is also known as the Sirajganj 3x225MW Combined Cycle Power Plant or the 220MW Surajganj Combined Cycle Dual Fuel Power Project. The Chinese project title is 孟加拉国希拉甘杰220MW联合循环电 站项目. The Bangla project title is সিরাজগঞ্জ ২২৫ মেঃওঃ কম্বাইন্ড সাইকেল বিদ্যুৎ কেন্দ্র (ইউনিট-২).  The first unit of electricity generators (Sirajganj 1) was commissioned in 2012. Construction of the third unit unit of electricity generators (Sirajganj 3) began in October 2017, and it began commercial operations on January 20, 2019. Sirajganj 3 was supported by a syndicated loan that included the provision of debt from Bank of China (see Project ID#69033). 

The project is located about 15 km south-east of Sirajganj town and 130 km north-west of Dhaka. The closest settlements to the project site, Boroshimul & Ponchosona, are both located approximately 1 km from the power plant complex. Natural gas, the main fuel for the project, will be supplied by Petrobangla, and there are already existing pipelines servicing the power plant complex for the Sirajganj 1 Project. Power from the project will be evacuated to the national grid through existing 230kV switching station beside the project site. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sirajganj+225+MW+Combined+Cycle+Power+Plant+(Unit-2/@24.3856385,89.7443028,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x39fde9033eb445ad:0x7cd2833dda7a0b37!8m2!3d24.3856336!4d89.7464915 and https://www.nwpgcl.org.bd/current-plant/sirajganj-225-mw-combined-cycle-power-plant-unit-2-
sources: http://www.ceec.net.cn/art/2017/10/25/art_11019_1501206.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.cggc.ceec.net.cn/art/2019/2/14/art_6858_1835858.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.google.com/search?q=yidaiyilu+%E5%B8%8C%E6%8B%89%E7%94%98%E6%9D%B0&oq=yidaiyilu+%E5%B8%8C%E6%8B%89%E7%94%98%E6%9D%B0&aqs=chrome..69i57.1446j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://news.cableabc.com/society/20180213160409.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2015/201807/P020180712414684910260.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

funding_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Dongfang Electric, State-owned Company
title: China provides CNY680 million in supplier's credit for Dongfang Electric Co to export 69 locomotives to Pakistan (Linked to projects #35120 and #56552)
description: In 2001, China and Pakistan signed an agreement to supply 69 locomotives and 175 passenger coaches worth 100 million USD to Pakistan to modernize its railway system. Under the contract, the Exim Bank of China will meet 87.5 per cent of the financial requirements of the export supplier credit basis, while the rest will be arranged by Pakistan Railways. The repayment period for the credit is 15 years. The grace period will be three years and the interest rate will be about five per cent. China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation will export the 175 passenger carriages. Another Chinese Company, Dongfang Electric Corporation (DEC) will provide altogether 69 modern locomotive engines worth 100 million USD to Pakistan within a period of two years. Under the agreement, 15 complete locomotives are to be manufactured in China, while the rest of 54 will be assembled in Pakistan. China will provide both spare parts and technology. According to the annual report by EXIM Bank of China of 2003, in March that year the bank agreed to provide CNY650 million (roughly the equivalent of USD100 million at the conversion rate of the time) in supplier's credits for China National Machinery, and later in July, the bank signed a similar deal with Donfang Electric Corporation for two lines of supplier's credit, one of CNY680 million and the other of USD4.6 million, to support the latter's export of 69 locomotives. This project captures the export of locomotives, specifically the loan denominated in Chinese Yuan. For details of the loan denominated for the same project in USD, see project #56552. For details of the other project involving railway coaches, see #35120. These are linked together because they are signed and implemented simultaneously.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=prn0000020011116dxbg000fc&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://finance.takungpao.com/q/2013/0913/1903430.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.mofcom.gov.cn/article/ztdy/200803/20080305410943.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=HNTM000020050714e17e000h5&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=HNTM000020050714e17e000h5&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=paprin0020010814dx8b0009s&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PAPRIN0020030531dz5t0005l&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020010709dx5b02y72&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcsap0020010710dx5b001qv&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2003/201807/P020180712541418438938.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020010709dx5a030yj&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=paprin0020010714dx5a00gew&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PAPRIN0020030714dz7c000d7&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Grants 712.6 million AFA to Afghan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (linked to #53879)
description: On November 4, 2008, China provided 712.6 million AFA to the Afghan Ministry of Foreign Affairs. From November 20, 2008, to December 21, 2019, China provides 858,140,268 Afghanistan Afghani (approx. 16.4 million USD) aids to Afghan Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The contribution was delivered over multiple years. About 97 million AFA (1.5 million USD) was spent. The funds were given in a grant used for acquisition of assets and the use of goods and services (#53879). DAD Platform Refer Project Code: AFG/230069; Old Project Code: AFG/0866901

From November 20, 2008, to December 21, 2019, China provides 858,140,268 Afghanistan Afghani (approx. 16.4 million USD) aids to Afghan Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The contribution was delivered over multiple years. About 97 million AFA (1.5 million USD) was spent. The funds were given in a grant used for acquisition of assets and the use of goods and services (#53879). DAD Platform Refer Project Code: AFG/230069; Old Project Code: AFG/0866901

funding_agencies: Chinese Embassy, Government Agency
title: Chinese Embassy in Afghanistan donated $5,000 for flood-related humanitarian aid (Linked to project #34522)
description: China donated55,000 to Afghanistan for flood and avalanche relief. The Chinese Red Cross Society contributed50,000 and the Chinese Embassy in Afghanistan contributed5,000. The cash was handed over to Fatima Gailani, the Head of the Afghan Red Crescent Society by Chinese ambassador to Afghanistan Yang Houlan at the Chinese Embassy on April 2, 2007. The project captures the donation by Chinese embassy; for the donation by Red Cross Society of China, see project #34522.
sources: http://www.gov.cn/misc/2007-04/02/content_569501.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020070402e3420063h&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://af.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/200704/20070404550512.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-owned Company
title: ICBC Loan to Lahore Orange Line Metro Project
description: In January 2017, the state owned Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) provided a Rs 1.36 billion short-term loan for the funding of the 27km Orange Line Metro Project in Pakistan. The terms of the loan are unclear, however the funds were provided to the Punjab Government in January 2017. Construction of the project is underway and is expected to be completed in 2019. The Orange Line Metro Project is a CPEC project.
sources: https://eproc.punjab.gov.pk/Tenders/37650_scan0329.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/46, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.icbc.com.cn/icbc/gxk_1/12551.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2017-02/08/content_28139148.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: China Export-Import Bank, State-owned Company
implementing_agencies: Kichi Chaarat Gold Mining Company, State-owned Company
title: China ExIm Bank Loan for Kuru-Tegerek Copper and Gold Resources Development Project in Kyrgyzstan
description: In July 2017, the China Eximbank signed a loan agreement with Kichi Chaarat gold mining company (also known as Kichi-Chaarat Closed Joint Stock Company), a subsidiary of China National Gold Group Corporation, to provide financing support for Kuru-Tegerek Copper and Gold Resources Development Project (or Kuru-Tegerek Copper and Gold Resources Development Project). This project is located in in Jalalabad, Kyrgyzstan. After completion, the mine is expected to have an annual processing capacity of about 1.8 million tons, including an annual output of 11,000 tons of copper, 600 kg of gold and 4.6 tons of silver. Estimated annual sales income from the mine is100 million. The mine is also expected to be the largest copper-gold mine and the largest underground mine in Kyrgyzstan. No sovereign guarantee was provided by the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic for this project. The amount of the loan is unclear.
sources: http://en.chinagoldcons.com/products_detail/productId=41.html, Other; https://www.dropbox.com/s/nk48wa62u3casfj/Re-%20Query%20re-%20China%20Eximbank%20loan%20for%20the%20Kuru-Tegerek%20Copper%20and%20Gold%20Resources%20Development%20Project.eml?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.cnmc.com.cn/zsgj/outlineentem.jsp?outlinetype=1&column_no=091402, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/info/news/201810/t20181031_7991.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
recipient_agencies: Kichi Chaarat Gold Mining Company, State-owned Company

funding_agencies: China Export-Import Bank, State-owned Company
title: China Exim Bank 450 Million RMB loan to supply telecommunication equipment to Ministry of Communication
description: The China Exim Bank is providing 450 million RMB for the supply of telecommunications equipment to the Turkmenistan Ministry of Communication. As of 2012, the project was still being implemented, according to a Turkmenistan State Bank Annual Report. This project may be part of China loans worth 650 million RMB to Turkmenistan for communications in 2005 (#40214) along with 200 million RMB export credits for telecommunications in 2006 (#40332). STAFF_NOTE: The original commitment date is unclear. The umbrella project of 650 million RMB was committed in 2005 and the 200 million RMB project was committed in 2006, so it is unlikely that the commitment year is 2011. The year is marked as 2006 to better reflect the transaction amount.
sources: http://www.tfeb.gov.tm/downloads/fs/2012/ar/en.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.tfeb.gov.tm/downloads/fs/2011/ar/en.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China grants 732,386 USD for response to natural disasters
description: In June 2010, Chinese President Hu Jintao announced 5 million RMB of assistance to Tajikistan to eliminate consequences of natural disasters. This project corresponds to TJK/102178 in the Tajikistan AIMS, which details a grant of 732,386 USD for 'assistance in natural disaster'. At the same time, the President also announced 80 million RMB to support the country's economy, which is captured in project ID #40409.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASIPLU0020100611e66b00030&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: China Export-Import Bank, State-owned Company; Turkmenneft, State-owned Company
title: China Exim Bank loans 400 million RMB to Turkmenneft for the supply of oil, gas equipment, and tubular goods
description: The China Exim Bank implemented a 400 million RMB credit to supply Turkmenneft for the supply of oil, gas equipment, and tubular goods. As of 2011, the project was still being implemented. STAFF_NOTE: The original commitment year of the loan is unclear, but 2011 is the first found source that lists the project.
sources: http://www.tfeb.gov.tm/downloads/fs/2012/ar/en.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.tfeb.gov.tm/downloads/fs/2011/ar/en.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Grants $20,400 to Tajikistan for Meteorological Management
description: In 2004, the Government of the People's Republic of China granted a20,400 project in Tajikistan for the meteorological management of the PRC, according to the Tajikistan AIMS platform (TJK/042055). STAFF_NOTE: This project was listed in the Tajikistan AIMS platform, which indicates that funds did go to Tajikistan, however the meteorological management is of the People's Republic of China, which does not seem logically consistent.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

funding_agencies: Chinese Government, Government Agency
title: China grants 764,526 to Tajikistan for Flood Relief (linked to #40441)
description: In 2011, the government of China granted 764,526 USD to Tajikistan in the form of humanitarian aid for flooding and other natural disasters. It is unclear which part of the Chinese government provided the funding. A May 2018 Flat Export of the Tajikistan AMP reports 'Humanitarian aid for flood and other disasters' in project TJK/112260. The first two digits indicate the year, leading to the assumption that this project. Though the Flat Export does not tie this project to a specific disaster, it is possible that the referenced flooding is the series of June 2011 floods and mudslides in Sughd province. This project should not be confused with project #40441, the 2012 natural disaster response from China to Tajikistan. The 2012 aid package primarily seeks to address the impact of an unusually cold winter, while the 2011 aid package primarily seeks to address a flood.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Other; https://reliefweb.int/disaster/ff-2011-000066-tjk, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy

funding_agencies: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency
title: CDB signs $650 million loan agreement with Kazakhstan Development Bank (year 2017) - drawn down amount (linked to project #53575)
description: In March 2017, China Development Bank provided a650 million loan to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, for joint Kazakh-Chinese projects in the transportation, infrastructure, and communication sectors. China and Kazakhstan agreed on the line of credit in 2015 and the facility agreement was amended in July 2016. As at 30 June 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the agreement was170 million. The loan matures in June 2025 and has an interest rate of 2.7% per annum plus LIBOR. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in March 2017 is used in the calculation of interest rate - 1.426% + 2.7% = 4.126% This project captures the drawn down amount of 480 million USD. The full amount is captured in umbrella project #53575. STAFF_NOTE: Not a duplicate of 53574 - 53574 was signed in March 2015 for the same amount. This project was signed in 2017.
sources: http://nationalbank.kz/cont/BoP_2016_eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.kdb.kz/upload/iblock/71d/AR2017_KDB_eng_site.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
recipient_agencies: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency

title: CDB signs $650 million loan agreement with Kazakhstan Development Bank (year 2015) - drawn down amount (Linked to #53574)
description: On 17 March 2015, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan (DBK) signed a650.0 million loan agreement with China Development Bank. Each loan under this loan agreement matures on 15 June 2025. As at 30 June 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under this loan agreement was U.S.$200.0 million. The funds will finance projects in energy, transport, infrastructure, manufacturing, information technologies, agriculture and other areas. This loan was identified by the DBK Annual Report 2015 as a credit line. This project captures the drawn down amount, the full amounts is captured in umbrella project #53574. STAFF_NOTE: Not a duplicate of 53575 - 53575 was signed in June 2017 for the same amount. This project was signed in 2015.
sources: http://nationalbank.kz/cont/BoP_2016_eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://uc920c267d56e444011c45cae5bc.previews.dropboxusercontent.com/nativeprint?file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dropbox.com%2Fs%2Fb8pbob8b1n7pwr1%2FDevelopment%2520Bank%2520of%2520Kazakhstan%25202017%2520Bond%2520Prospectus.pdf%3Fdisable_range%3D1%26from_native_print%3D1%26preview%3D1, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dbk.kz/upload/iblock/ed6/ed6ac0af95e1030652f131a159ff8b7a.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
